urn:contentItem:6DTB-P7N3-RT6M-63FH-00000-00Rain interrupts strategic backburning operations on the Attunga Forest fire2025-01-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:20ZLexisNexisRain interrupts strategic backburning operations on the Attunga Forest fireEmma Downey

Light rain on Thursday evening, January 2, hampered strategic backburning on the Attunga State Forest bushfire, but the NSW Rural Fire Service (RFS) aims to have the incident under control by Friday.

The RFS has set up a new bush fire information point at Northgate shopping centre in front of Coles supermarket as backburning operations increase the level of smoke across Tamworth.

RFS manager for community risk for the North West Area Command, Shellie Smyth, said the latest bushfire information point will operate between 11am and 6pm on Friday, January 3, and provide "greater exposure" to the local community impacted by the fire.

"Our community engagement team members will be available to provide any assistance or give information to the public that is concerned about the fires," she said.

"The bush fire information point at Moore Creek station on Thursday, January 2, was held off the back of a really successful community meeting the night before, so we're feeling quite comfortable the community is well informed about the situation.

"Moving into town widens our access to the public, enabling us to provide a greater number of community members with any advice or guidance they might need, particularly with backburning operations' smoke coming into Tamworth."

The RFS has also deployed field officers to undertake door-knocking to provide additional information to local fire-affected communities.

Ms Smyth said up to five millimetres fell across the Attunga fire ground late yesterday, making conditions "pretty slippery and risky for our teams".

"They were back out on the job today, and will continue to strengthen containment lines around the Attunga fire throughout today," she said.

"The rain did prevent some of the backburning operations we had planned; however, the RFS continued to prepare properties around Stirling Road for the backburns, which will continue today.

"We will continue to strengthen containment lines around properties in the Stirling Road area and also in other sectors, particularly on the eastern side of the fire."

Ms Smyth said the Attunga fire is holding steady at around 610 hectares in size.

Some support crews head home Some of the out-of-area crews from the Greater Sydney region will start to head home on Saturday, January 4, while those remaining will continue to support local crews.

A small fire, two-hectare fire occurred along Barry Road at Hanging Rock on Thursday evening, however Ms Smyth said the RFS drew on resources working on Bowling Alley Point fire, now under control, to quickly respond and contain the blaze.

Ms Smyth said lightning strikes associated with recent storm activity passing through the area had been responsible for igniting the majority of fires across the region in the past week.

urn:contentItem:6G59-VCF3-RSH5-C277-00000-00Western Europe heatwave fuels fires and closes schools as records tumble2025-06-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:20ZLexisNexisWestern Europe heatwave fuels fires and closes schools as records tumbleBy Europe correspondent Elias Clure and Patrick Martin in London and wires 

Temperatures in some parts of Western Europe exceed 46 degrees Celsius, with fires burning in two countries and respite from the heat not expected for at least a few days.

A heatwave is gripping several European countries, with the soaring temperatures fanning fires, closing schools and breaking heat records. 

One expert has described the weather event as "remarkable" for its timing, size and extreme temperatures, warning that more heatwaves like this will likely occur across the world because of human-induced climate change.

From the United Kingdom to Germany, authorities are grappling with the heat, which in some parts is 5 to 10 degrees Celsius warmer than usual for this time of year.

Wildfires in Türkiye have forced more than 50,000 people to be evacuated from five regions in the western province of Izmir.

Scientists say human-induced climate change is making the country's coastal regions hotter and drier, with fires hitting coastal areas hard in recent years.

In Seville, where global leaders were meeting for a United Nations conference on Monday, it was forecast to reach 42C.

In France, some 200 schools will be partially closed over the next three days because of the heat.

France's national meteorological service, Meteo France, put a record 84 of 101 regions across the country on orange alert until at least mid-week.

The first significant forest fire of the season burnt through 400 hectares of woodlands on Sunday and Monday in Aude in the country's south.

Italy's health ministry put 21 cities under red alert, warning people of heat-related health risks regardless of their prior condition.

Spain is heading for its hottest June on record, the country's meteorological service said.

The country appeared to hit a new high for June on Saturday, when 46 degrees Celsius was recorded in the southern province of Huelva.

Spain's national average of 28C on Sunday set a record for a high temperature for June 29 since records were started in 1950.

Portugal also recorded a record high for June at the weekend, when 46.6C was recorded at Mora, 100 kilometres east of Lisbon.

German authorities were urging people to limit their use of water as temperatures climbed to 34C in some parts of the country's west and south-west.

Europe heatwave 'remarkable', expert says

The strategic lead for climate at the European Centre for Medium Range Forecasts and deputy director of the European Union's Copernicus Climate Change Service, Samantha Burgess, said it was a unique heat event for several reasons.

She said the temperatures seen across large parts of Europe would usually be seen in late July or early August.

"It's remarkable for the intensity of the maximum temperatures forecast over a large part of Western Europe, it's remarkable for the geographical extent … and it's remarkable for its earliness as well," Dr Burgess told the ABC.

"Europe is the fastest-warming continent, with temperatures rising at about twice the global average rate and the three warmest years on record for Europe have all occurred since 2020."

The reason Europe was warming faster than the rest of the world, she said, was down to three factors.

"Land areas are warming faster than the ocean — Europe has a lot of land in it," she said.

"The Arctic is the fastest-warming region on our planet, and it is warming at three to four times the global average rate. The proximity of the Arctic and parts of the Arctic within the European domain in Scandinavia and the Nordic countries [is having an impact]."

She also said improving air quality was also having an effect, because a reduction in pollutants meant a reduction in low-level clouds, which previously reflected the Sun's energy back into space.

"Without those low-level clouds that reflect the sun's energy back into space, we're getting clearer skies in Europe and clearer skies mean we're getting more of the Sun's radiation hitting the surface of the Earth," she said.

She said that human-induced climate change would likely result in "more heatwaves that are more intense, that last longer and that impact a larger region".

"2024 was the warmest year on record, followed by 2023, and 2025 is on track to be probably the third warmest year on record," she said.

"The only way that we are going to reduce future warming of our planet … is rapid greenhouse gas emissions reductions and getting to net zero as quickly as possible."

Hottest day one at Wimbledon on record

The Wimbledon tennis tournament had its hottest-ever first day of play on record, with temperatures hitting 33C on Monday at the All England Club in London.

The previous record of 29.3C was set in 2001.

London's average daytime temperature in June is 21.5C.

Tennis enthusiasts fanned themselves or sought shade from the blazing sun as the first day of matches got underway.

Fan Devon Anand told the ABC the heat was "unbearable."

"We've been in the queue for seven hours, and that killed us," he said after deciding to leave the tournament late in the afternoon to get some rest.

He was one of the lucky ones who managed to see some tennis after joining the famous queue, which is the only way people can buy tickets on the day of the event.

More than 10,000 people queued to get a ticket on day one despite the heat.

Steve and Jane Lenton waited for five hours, before giving up and going home.

"It hasn't been the best day," Mr Lenton said.

When temperatures reach 30.1C or above, players can take an extended 10-minute break during their matches.

The break can be taken between the second and third sets in a women's match and between the third and fourth sets of a men's match.

"You feel like the sun is getting closer and closer every minute that passes by," said Adrian Mannarino, a 37-year-old Frenchman who frequently sprayed his shaved head with sunscreen at changeovers during his first-round victory.

The hot weather is expected to ease across the UK and Europe from mid-week.

urn:contentItem:6G8D-H9P3-RRW8-20J9-00000-00'THANK GOD IT WASN'T A TURKEY'2025-07-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:20ZLexisNexisLIFEPg. 12'THANK GOD IT WASN'T A TURKEY'John Jurgensen

Here, in his own words, actor Michael Douglas reveals the backstory behind the 1975 hit film One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest Jack Nicholson starred in One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest, but a future leading man of Hollywood put the film together. Michael Douglas produced the 1975 box-office hit before his own movie career took off. In his late 20s, Douglas got the rights to adapt Ken Kesey's 1962 novel from his father, Kirk Douglas, who originated the lead role of Randle McMurphy, a maverick who up-ends a psychiatric ward, in a 1963 Broadway production. The film won five Academy awards, including best picture and Oscars for Nicholson, Nurse Ratched actor Louise Fletcher and director Milos Forman. For the film's 50th anniversary, Fathom Entertainment is releasing a restored version this week.

The book made a tremendous impression on me in college and I saw my father in the stage production. He had bought rights to the book when it was in galley form. After the play he tried for about five years to set the picture up. I said, "Let me try to run with it." Dad said, "Sure, give the kid a chance." I would try to get him the money he wanted and the part of McMurphy in the movie.

In my dad's files on the project I found this company, Fantasy Records in Berkeley, California, run by a gentleman named Saul Zaentz. In the 60s, Fantasy had a band called the Golliwogs, which became Creedence Clearwater Revival. It was the profits from Creedence that would pay for Cuckoo's Nest. John Fogerty from Creedence later had a pretty substantial lawsuit against Saul over music profits.

We put together a deal where I would share half of my back-end profits with my father. Our budget was a couple million when we started and ended up at about $4m, which was more than most independent movies. Saul's partners thought I was railroading him and taking all the money out of Fantasy.

At the time I was on a crime show called The Streets of San Francisco with Karl Malden. It was a hit and I had Emmy nominations and a five-year contract, but I asked to leave early to produce this picture.

Saul and I made mistakes but we also trusted our instincts. Instead of using a stage in Hollywood, we decided to shoot the film on location. In Oregon. In January. When it gets dark at three in the afternoon. In a hospital ward. For verisimilitude.

But it was one of those fateful decisions because we found the Oregon State Hospital and the superintendent, Dean Brooks, became an extraordinary collaborator. He ended up playing the part of McMurphy's doctor. He also allowed the actors into group therapy sessions and he suggested patients to actually be part of our crew. We had an arsonist working in the art department.

I remember walking through these empty wards of the hospital. It was a very isolated, lonely place that we were able to bring all this life to. We had two weeks of rehearsal before we started, and several of the actors were sleeping at the hospital.

Did I consider trying to play McMurphy? No, I was 29 years old. McMurphy had to be a little bit over the hill. Gene Hackman and Marlon Brando had turned it down. For a while Milos was seriously thinking about Burt Reynolds. I always felt bad about my father not getting the part. But Jack was such a good choice to be our guide into this world, with that sly angle that it was going to be easier than jail time for him. It did cross my mind that maybe I could play Billy Bibbit. Then Brad Dourif came in for an audition, and I just said, "Well, that's our Billy." Will Sampson, who played Chief Bromden, was one of those casting dreams. I got a call about him from a used-car salesman I had met on an aeroplane. Will was working as a forest-fire ranger in Yakima, Washington, and he flew down to Portland to meet us for the first time. So we're down there at the gate waiting, and Will comes through the gate with his cowboy hat and boots that made him close to 7 feet tall. Jack goes, "Oh, my god, it's the Chief!" Will flew back with us in this twin engine plane that was very small. So he sat in the front seat and Jack sat in his lap. He just kept saying, "It's the Chief, man, it's the Chief!" We had some trouble because at first Milos wasn't showing footage to the cast. And our cinematographer, Haskell Wexler, didn't like what Milos was doing and that was beginning to leak into the cast. So I had to fire Haskell. I felt like an idiot going up to this super-talented man who was old enough to be my father but it had to be done.

We also had a big drama with William Redfield, who played Harding. We discovered he had leukaemia and we had to gamble on whether he could finish the picture. He passed away a couple of weeks after the picture was over. His performance was just magical.

We kept pushing Milos to get out of the hospital, but he was resisting the idea of shooting the scenes where McMurphy steals the fishing boat. We finally did it and the cast was violently seasick. I remember Danny DeVito on the morning of the third day crying, "I can't go out!" At first we didn't really know what the purpose of the fishing trip was but then it became about the patients coming together as a group and recognising McMurphy was the leader.

On set, we were rocking. Jack improvised a lot to McMurphy calling the imaginary baseball game because Jack knew his sports, but everything was pretty scripted.

To this day it's an acting lesson. I can show you a 1000-foot roll of film, 10 minutes of Jack saying nothing, simply doing reactions to the group therapy meeting, and you'll be mesmerised.

The film is a star vehicle for Jack, but it's an ensemble film at its heart. What we're seeing on the screen is camaraderie and I think that's why it stood the test of time. It's also a funny movie. Yes it gets sad, but when the Chief breaks out and Christopher Lloyd is triumphant, it ends on a very positive note. I think that's partly why it succeeded.

When the picture was finished, we went looking for distribution but could not make a deal with anybody. The studios saw the exact same movie that would get nominated for nine Oscars but they all turned us down.

United Artists, respectfully, was like your last choice in those days but they made us a decent deal. Then they went on a run. They won best picture three years in a row starting with us, then Rocky, then Annie Hall.

Saul Zaentz won three best picture awards in his career, including Amadeus in the 80s, and The English Patient in the 90s. I don't think he's ever given proper credit, probably because he was from the outside.

It was an independent picture that was signed, sealed and delivered to the studio. It certainly brought in a lot of money for us in the first 25 years, and now we have receipts for 50 years. For Jack in particular it was a very financially rewarding film.

I used to tease my father that his half of my back end was more money than he ever made for any picture in his career. For him the money helped ease the pain, but not by much, of not getting the role of McMurphy. Now I'm old enough to understand that you get maybe four really good parts in your life if you're lucky, and that certainly seemed like one of those parts to my father.

Thank god the movie wasn't a turkey! That was probably the most nervous I was when I invited Dad up to see our first cut of the movie. He was a fan. He complimented Jack and what a beautiful job we did. His running joke after that was, "If I knew Michael was going to be so successful, I would have been nicer to him!" I was recently in a picture with my older son Cameron, and my younger ones are just starting in the business. I really take offence to this term "nepo babies". It's a nasty slap. Oh yeah, I know how it feels. My dad would say, "Son, you have it much harder than me. I had the rags-to-riches story, but people think of you as a kid with a silver spoon in your mouth." THE WALL STREET JOURNAL

urn:contentItem:6G6V-7BS3-RYYV-F4FR-00000-00Merger will not restore deleted emergency capability2025-07-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:20ZLexisNexisMerger will not restore deleted emergency capability

Victorian Fisheries Media Centre, The Buloke Times

The anticipated merger of the Victorian Fisheries Authority with the Game Management Authority this week – reported online by "The Weekly Times" – might salvage some enforcement clout from the recent sacking of almost half the state's Fisheries Officers, but it will not make up for a separate decision to bar all remaining officers from responding to emergencies.

On May 20, 2025, the fisheries authority (VFA) finalised an organisational restructure, under which it has since shed 30 (44 per cent) of the state's 69 Fisheries Officers; leaving just 39 officers to patrol Victoria's 2,512-kilometre coastline, 10,000 square-kilometres of ocean waters and 170,000 kilometres of inland water frontage along 85,000 kilometres of rivers and creeks.

Then in a separate decision, on Friday, June 13, 2025, the VFA stripped the remaining officers of their duties to "respond to any emergency" by deleting these duties from their Position Descriptions.

This decision was communicated by email from the authority's human resources manager to an organiser at the state branch of the Community and Public Sector Union (CPSU Vic) at 5:13 p.m..

Controversy

It also came amid statewide controversy over the Allan Government's new Emergency Services and Volunteers Fund (ESVF) and whether it will actually deliver value for rural ratepayers, or subsidise Fire Rescue Victoria service provision to urban areas and metropolitan Melbourne.

When interviewed on ABC Statewide Drive in Ballarat on June 25, 2025, the new Emergency Management Commissioner, Tim Wiebusch, was asked whether Fisheries Officers fell within his "remit" – and under his management – in an emergency.

Co-ordination

"The role that I'm in now has a role in providing co-ordination across all our government departments and agencies and that does include the likes of the Victorian Fisheries Authority... because they provide support to a range of emergencies," Commissioner Wiebusch said.

"They have a high level of on-water capability."

Under Section 8(kc) of the Victorian Fisheries Authority Act 2016, it is a statutory function of Fisheries Officers "to respond to any emergency..."

The June 13 decision of the fisheries authority will have the effect of permanently preventing Fisheries Officers from providing that function in future, regardless of the Emergency Management Commissioner's expectations when the next emergency happens.

The fisheries authority on May 20 confirmed, in response to a Freedom of Information request, that it implemented its 2025 workplace changes – which involve both the shedding of frontline personnel and reductions in the duties of remaining staff – without a risk assessment.

Mr Wiebusch told the ABC that SES, Catchment Management authorities, Lifesaving Victoria and Victoria Police also operated boats and could be called upon, if the Victorian Fisheries Authority could no longer be called out.

No contact

None of these organisations or agencies have been contacted to confirm their equivalence to the "high level of on-water capability" of professional Fisheries Officers, nor has the Allan Government announced supplementary funding for this purpose.

However, the Premier's Office did reportedly tell Ballarat newspaper "The Courier" that the Victorian Fisheries Authority is "not an emergency service."

Neither the Catchment Management authorities, Lifesaving Victoria, Victoria Police, nor the Victorian Fisheries Authority are funded for their emergency work from the Emergency Services and Volunteers Fund, and neither do they fall under the jurisdiction of the Inspector-General for Emergency Management.

An entire page of the Emergency Management Victoria (EMV) website is filled by the Role statement – Victorian Fisheries Authority. It specifically details the critical roles of Fisheries Officers in responding to multiple categories of general and specialist emergencies.

Serious gap

Permanently stripping Fisheries Officers of their duties to "to respond to any emergency" will leave a serious capability gap in the State Emergency Management Plan (SEMP) and significantly undermine Victoria's counter-disaster resilience.

Former Chief Commissioner of Victoria Police, Kel Glare, his Community Advocacy Alliance and more than 12,900 concerned Victorians have so far hit back with an online petition for an inquiry into the fisheries authority, because the restructure had gone ahead without a risk assessment.

Skills and experience

In the past five years alone, the skills and experience of Fisheries Officers were not only of critical and strategic importance, but indispensable in the safe and expeditious execution of co-ordinated emergency responses to at least two major disasters in this state: the 2020 East Gippsland bushfires and the 2022 Goulburn Valley floods.

In October 2022, Greater Shepparton was impacted by significant and widespread flooding due to intense rainfalls in the catchment areas of the Goulburn and Broken rivers.

Veteran retired Supervising Fisheries Officer and sometimes Regional Manager (North East), Greg Sharp, was the Operations Lead for the Victorian Fisheries Authority, in the Incident Control Centre, during the 2022 Goulburn Valley floods.

He said the rainfall caused the rivers to rise rapidly, leading to extensive flooding in urban and rural areas.

"Fisheries Officers, having specialist skills and experience in the operation of suitable vessels for the circumstances, were mustered from all over Victoria," Mr Sharp said.

Support

"Our boat crews provided round-the-clock support to Ambulance Victoria and GV Health, and relief agencies – Salvation Army, Society of St Vincent de Paul – delivering food and emergency medicine to householders stranded by flood waters in and around Shepparton and Tatura.

"Fisheries Officers also assisted with wildlife management in the weeks after the floods receded, assisting professional shooters to euthanise stranded wildlife otherwise facing a slow lingering death from starvation. This was no fly-by-night operation, it went on for weeks!"

Mr Sharp said Fisheries Officers also provided indispensable water-borne transport services during and after the January 2020 Mallacoota bushfires which destroyed 123 houses – including five owned by CFA volunteers – and 65 sheds.

"In the immediate aftermath of the 2020 fires, the only road into Mallacoota was utterly impassable; littered with debris and lined with scorched trees ready to shed limbs at the slightest breeze," Mr Sharp said.

"It was therefore necessary for Fisheries Officers – in Kevlacat patrol vessels – to ferry supplies, personnel and essential equipment into the town by sea from Lakes Entrance. There was so much smoke in the air, flying in was not an option. Aircraft were grounded!"

He said personnel ferried in and out by Fisheries Officers included Country Fire Authority relief crews, needed to complete the mopping-up after the initial major firefight and to respond if smouldering tree roots or other hidden detritus flared-up again.

And when the Fisheries Officers were not boating into Mallacoota, they were just as busy landing supplies and Forest Fire Management Victoria firefighters on to beaches in the remote Croajingolong National Park via Mallacoota Inlet.

"Not even the navy could get in. Our vessels provided the necessary shuttle service between offshore vessels and onshore landing points; whether they be the wharf, a jetty or one of the beaches," Mr Sharp said.

"Of course, our people did not just turn up after the event. They went in while the fire was still raging, to engage in a daring race against time, to capture and evacuate by sea many critically endangered eastern bristlebirds nesting in the paths of approaching fire fronts."

Mr Sharp said that while these fires and floods had happened within the past five years, they also typified a long history of major-disaster emergency responses by a great many Fisheries Officers who, since the 1950s, were subsequently decorated for their extraordinary service.

"Yes, I was awarded an NEM (National Emergency Medal) for my participation as a Fisheries Officer in responding to the 2009 Black Saturday bushfires," Mr Sharp said.

Link to Image

This article appeared in The Buloke Times, 4 July 2025.

urn:contentItem:6DTB-F483-RTS4-J3SX-00000-00Rain interrupts strategic backburning operations on the Attunga Forest fire2025-01-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:20ZLexisNexisRain interrupts strategic backburning operations on the Attunga Forest fireEmma Downey

RFS aims to soon have the Attunga fire at 'controlled' status.

Light rain on Thursday evening, January 2, hampered strategic backburning on the Attunga State Forest bushfire, but the NSW Rural Fire Service (RFS) aims to have the incident under control by Friday.

The RFS has set up a new bush fire information point at Northgate shopping centre in front of Coles supermarket as backburning operations increase the level of smoke across Tamworth.

RFS manager for community risk for the North West Area Command, Shellie Smyth, said the latest bushfire information point will operate between 11am and 6pm on Friday, January 3, and provide "greater exposure" to the local community impacted by the fire.

"Our community engagement team members will be available to provide any assistance or give information to the public that is concerned about the fires," she said.

"The bush fire information point at Moore Creek station on Thursday, January 2, was held off the back of a really successful community meeting the night before , so we're feeling quite comfortable the community is well informed about the situation.

"Moving into town widens our access to the public, enabling us to provide a greater number of community members with any advice or guidance they might need, particularly with backburning operations' smoke coming into Tamworth."

The RFS has also deployed field officers to undertake door-knocking to provide additional information to local fire-affected communities.

Ms Smyth said up to five millimetres fell across the Attunga fire ground late yesterday, making conditions "pretty slippery and risky for our teams".

"They were back out on the job today, and will continue to strengthen containment lines around the Attunga fire throughout today," she said.

"The rain did prevent some of the backburning operations we had planned; however, the RFS continued to prepare properties around Stirling Road for the backburns, which will continue today.

"We will continue to strengthen containment lines around properties in the Stirling Road area and also in other sectors, particularly on the eastern side of the fire."

Ms Smyth said the Attunga fire is holding steady at around 610 hectares in size.

Some support crews head home

Some of the out-of-area crews from the Greater Sydney region will start to head home on Saturday, January 4, while those remaining will continue to support local crews.

A small fire, two-hectare fire occurred along Barry Road at Hanging Rock on Thursday evening, however Ms Smyth said the RFS drew on resources working on Bowling Alley Point fire, now under control, to quickly respond and contain the blaze.

Ms Smyth said lightning strikes associated with recent storm activity passing through the area had been responsible for igniting the majority of fires across the region in the past week .

urn:contentItem:6FG7-CH53-RSS1-W03H-00000-00PIECE OF MIND2025-04-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:20ZLexisNexisLETTERSPg. 37PIECE OF MIND

We've just had major stock losses in Australia from floods. We won't have beef left to export ('US farmer group calls for quota on Aussie beef imports', theweeklytimes.com.au, March 28).

Vivien

The USA is that short on red meat now. They are paying record prices for beef. How expensive do they want it to be?

Benjamin

Get the community to band together and get more enrolments to make it viable ('Loved rural primary school to close', March 28). We saved our school after it was put into recess, took four years and so much energy.

Mary-Therese

Our wonderful little school at Torrumbarry shut a decade plus ago, another nail in the coffin of rural life and a generation of children who grow up not knowing anyone or being known. Sad to see.

Marty

Making more national parks when they can't manage the existing ones is a disgrace. If governments can't keep them clean by doing regular burn-offs let the local community or Aboriginal groups do it ('Fire ire: Farmers call for change', March 26).

Denis

Plenty of flash Forest Fire Management vehicles around so there's no shortage of money.

Mark

To the person/people stealing the Dan Tehan, Liberal signs from my farm fence lines; what a disgraceful act. If only you were half the man Dan is. Megan

urn:contentItem:6FK9-DV53-RTW5-S462-00000-00Investigation into escaped planned burn south-west of Daylesford under way2025-04-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:20ZLexisNexisInvestigation into escaped planned burn south-west of Daylesford under wayAdam Spencer

FFMV says it will consider any recommendations made.

The fire authority responsible for a planned burn that breached containment lines in the Hepburn Regional Park and ignited a bushfire will consider "any recommendations for improvement" from an investigation.

The blaze ignited about 5.30pm last Friday from a planned 200-hectare burn that was started the day before. The bushfire burnt 98 hectares of the forest over a number of days.

Forest Fire Management Grampians Deputy Chief Fire Officer Jason Hellyer said an investigation was under way.

"We are cooperating with the Office of Bushfire Risk Management as they investigate the planned burn breach and will consider any recommendations for improvement," he said.

Warnings were issued for several towns in the fire's path, prompting many to evacuate, as hundreds of firefighters worked on the blaze. It was finally contained on Sunday afternoon.

"Our crews will continue to patrol the fire," Mr Hellyer said. "Local road closures will likely remain in place across the long weekend, with Stoney Creek Road and Ridge Road between Old-Ballarat Road and the Ballan-Daylesford Road open for residents only."

The planned burn was one of several taking place over the course of last week and the weekend.

Many on social media have been critical of the decision to ignite the burn, arguing it should not have been lit given the warmer weather in the region.

A Department of Energy, Environment and Climate Action spokesperson said it works with the Bureau of Meteorology to look at weather conditions and will only carry out planned burns when those conditions are suitable and it is safe to do so.

An investigation into a planned burn that got out of control in the Hepburn Regional Park is under way. Signs were displayed in the area (inset) of the fire as the planned burn continued on Friday, April 11, 2025. Pictures by Kate Healy

urn:contentItem:6C1K-K931-JBJ7-N0MB-00000-00Endangered greater glider found dead next to department's felling site2025-02-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:20ZLexisNexisEndangered greater glider found dead next to department's felling siteBianca Hall

Conservationists are furious after they warned the government about the presence of greater gliders and Leadbeater's possums in trees identified for removal.

An endangered greater glider has been found dead next to a Victorian Department of Environment tree-felling operation in the Yarra Ranges National Park, sparking a furious response from conservationists.

Forest Fire Management Victoria, which operates within the department, has been removing what it says are hazardous trees in the national park to maintain a "strategic fuel break".

Victorian National Parks Association executive director Matt Ruchel said his organisation had on May 6 warned the fire management agency, the department secretary, and federal and state ministers' offices about sightings of greater gliders and Leadbeater's possums in trees identified for removal.

The dead glider was found near the southern boundary of the Yarra Ranges National Park.

The find comes after a campaign by the Victorian National Parks Association and others to halt the removal of old-habitat trees in the park.

"We are furious at this deadly failure to take the survival of threatened wildlife seriously," Ruchel said.

"State and federal environment ministers need to fulfil their responsibilities and stop these works immediately. The situation urgently requires a full and proper ecological assessment."

Greater gliders and Leadbeater's possums rely on hollow-bearing trees for habitat and survival, making them particularly vulnerable to felling and fires.

Greater gliders - scientific name Petauroides volans - are now so rare that the species was in 2022 listed as endangered, a classification the federal government gives to animals at imminent risk of extinction in the wild.

Environmental Justice Australia special counsel Danya Jacobs said the destruction of habitat critical for endangered species was clearly breaking federal environment laws designed to protect greater gliders and Leadbeater's possums.

"Destroying scores of ancient hollow-bearing trees home to critically endangered Leadbeater's possums and endangered greater gliders, and killing those species in the process, is plainly illegal under federal environment law, and it has to stop," Jacobs said.

Environmental Justice Australia wrote to federal Environment Minister Tanya Plibersek and Victorian Environment Minister Steve Dimopoulos on Wednesday, detailing allegations that the Forest Fire Management Victoria operations are in contravention of the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999.

The act requires the referral, assessment and approval of all operations likely to have "significant impacts" on listed threatened species.

"We specifically told the government that greater gliders were nesting in this tree," Wildlife of the Central Highlands spokesperson Blake Nisbet said.

"This is disgraceful, and has to stop. Even when notified of the presence of a federally listed threatened wildlife, the information was ignored - with deadly consequences."

Forest Fire Management Victoria chief fire officer Chris Hardman said every effort was made to minimise impacts on flora and fauna.

"We ... follow a rigorous planning and approvals process to ensure we're consistent with the Forests Act, Flora and Fauna Guarantee Act and Wildlife Act," Hardman said.

"These fuel breaks are critical to enable firefighters to carry out back-burning in the event of a major bushfire, protect Melbourne's main water supply and prevent or lessen the impact of large-scale bushfires that can lead to mass wildlife deaths."

WWF conservation scientist Dr Kita Ashman said hollow trees were "like gold" for forest-dwelling mammals like greater gliders. "Hollows can take hundreds of years to form and without hollows greater gliders and many other threatened species simply can't survive," she said.

"It's outrageous that despite warnings these trees had precious, occupied hollows, they were levelled anyway and at least one glider killed. A tree planted right now will not have a usable greater glider hollow in our lifetime. It's no wonder we face an extinction crisis."

A Department of Environment spokesman said staff would visit the site and determine the glider's cause of death.

"It's outrageous that despite warnings these trees had precious, occupied hollows, they were levelled anyway and at least one glider killed. A tree planted right now will not have a usable greater glider hollow in our lifetime. It's no wonder we face an extinction crisis."

A Department of Environment spokesman said staff would visit the site and determine the glider's cause of death.

urn:contentItem:6FG3-X643-S98M-F410-00000-00Why 2025 was the worst fire season since Black Summer - and what it means for 20262025-04-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:20ZLexisNexisWhy 2025 was the worst fire season since Black Summer - and what it means for 2026

Document links may not lead to an active page. Page maintenance is at the discretion of the publisher.

Abby Walter

Victoria's most recent fire season was the most devastating since Black Summer, with authorities already bracing for a tough 2026.

In 2025 fires burnt 320,434ha in Victoria - equivalent to the Melbourne CBD burning more than 155 times over.

Despite this there remained a significant load of fuel across the state heading into autumn and winter months where little rain was expected.

Last season's fires burnt about 70,000ha more than the average amount of land torched by fires in the past decade.

The only other season to do this was the 2019-20 Black Summer fires.

Lightning started a fire in the Little Desert National Park in January 2025 which burnt more than 95,000ha, while two fires in the Grampians burnt a combined 120,000ha.

Dimboola Fire Brigade captain Lyndon Kuhne said he had been fighting fires for nearly 20 years and had never seen a fire behave the way it did.

"For a small town like Dimboola, where everyone knows each other, the emotional weight was immense," he said.

"It's incredibly tough knowing you're responsible for protecting both your town and your personal world."

But Mr Kuhne said Dimboola's community spirit shone in the weeks after the fire.

"Protecting the town was truly a team effort, and together we succeeded," he said.

Mirranatwa Fire Brigade captain Jarrod Dark said Grampians fires were impossible to completely completely.

"When you're out at the back of your property and you can see the flames, it's confronting," he said.

"You hear the fire, and it sounds like a jet engine because of the pure power of it.

"There was a staggering amount of Forest Fire Management Victoria, CFA and interstate crews out there doing their best to contain and control the fire."

Mr Dark said it was lucky the Grampians had a tight knit community.

"Everyone was pitching in and doing their bit," he said.

"We're grateful beyond words for every CFA member, emergency responder, and community member who played a role."

In the past 10 years nearly 11 per cent of Victoria's total land mass has been burnt by fire.

During the 2019-2020 Black Summer fires the amount of land burnt was equivalent to 2610 Melbourne CBDs.

While fewer than 10,000ha were torched in 2021 - the season following Black Summer - it did not mean this trend would continue, with fire authorities bracing for a gruelling 2026.

Country Fire Authority chief officer Jason Heffernan said dry conditions and an active fire season were expected for next summer.

He said historically seasons with less hectares burnt had been wet La Nina years but there was no regular pattern.

"Severe rainfall deficits remain right across western Victoria and, despite all the bushfires this season, there are still many high-risk bushfire areas in the west, such as the Otways National Park and Wombat State Forest that have not had major bushfires for many years, as well as other areas of the state, which could be susceptible next season," he said.

"When underlying dryness persists multi-year it becomes harder to recover.

"Significant rainfall is required to deeply saturate soils and reduce flammability, which would mean consecutive months of well-above normal rainfall.

"At the end March, there are no indications of this being likely through autumn and winter this year."

Ahead of the 2024-25 summer the Australian Seasonal Bushfire Outlook indicated a lack of rainfall created more fuel available to burn across parts of the state and that there would be a higher chance of warmer maximum temperatures.

Forest Fire Management Victoria chief fire officer Chris Hardman said crews worked to reduce bushfire risk year-round.

"With the fire risk being higher than average this autumn, we urge people to take extreme care if lighting campfires, undertaking private burn-offs, or working with machinery in dry parts of the state," he said.

urn:contentItem:6FJM-T9J3-RY9R-Y502-00000-00Out-of-control bushfire in central Victoria within 100m of private property2025-04-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:20ZLexisNexisOut-of-control bushfire in central Victoria within 100m of private property

An out-of-control bushfire in central Victoria has come within 100 metres of private property, but authorities say fire behaviour dropped off on Sunday afternoon.

Authorities say weather conditions have been "testing" as fire crews attempt to contain anout-of-control bushfire in central Victoria.

Forest Fire Management Victoria chief fire officer Chris Hardman said containment efforts had gone well on Sunday afternoon, despite low humidity and winds picking up."The fire behaviour has dropped off," Mr Hardman said.

"We're hoping to deliver some good news to the community by tomorrow morning."

More than 250 firefighters have been deployed to the bushfire near the Old Tom Track in Hepburn Regional Park, south-west of Daylesford.

Fire authorities confirmed they lost control of a 200-hectare planned burn on Friday, which grew to 300 hectares on Sunday.

A Watch and Act warning is in place for communities south-west of Daylesford, including Sailors Hill, Sailors Falls and Musk Vale.

On Sunday, the blaze came within 100 metres of properties.Musk Vale resident Tracey Petrie said people in the area were "very, very nervous" they could lose their homes.

Ms Petrie, who is in the final stages of building a house in Musk Vale, said without a water connection she "couldn't do anything" to protect her property."Most of my neighbours have been watering their gardens all last night, all day today, and they have their bags packed," Ms Petrie said.

"Unfortunately my property doesn't have water tanks in it because they don't arrive for another two weeks."

She said her property had been inundated by ash and smoke, and there was little she could do to "wet down" her house or prevent spot fires without access to water.

Communities have been advised to remain on high alert and monitor changing conditions.

urn:contentItem:6FB8-CJ23-RTF5-K0NM-00000-00Struggling to cope: farmer feels 'disposable' amid bushfire battle2025-03-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:20ZLexisNexisStruggling to cope: farmer feels 'disposable' amid bushfire battleJessica Greenan

So far, 56 hectares of private land have been impacted.

As a bushfire rages through the Budj Bim National Park , the owner of a historic farming property nearby worries about what he might lose this time.

Dejavu has struck Grafton Millard owner Craig Millard as he watches the growing blaze - which began by lightning - reach its fifth day.

His family has farmed the area since the mid-1800s and has witnessed fires before, most notably in 2019 and 2020.

Watching the fire now grow to about 1300 hectares, Mr Millard can't help but feel anger.

So far, 56 hectares of private land have been impacted.

With Saturday forecast to be a bad fire danger day, Mr Millard said he was concerned.

But incident controller at the Heywood Incident Control Centre Trevor Dess said the fire wasn't expected to reach Mr Millard's property.

"Our fire behaviour analyst has modelled the potential spread of fire out to Wednesday March 19, the currently available forecast period," he said.

"The prediction shows that Mr Millard's property is not anticipated to be impacted."

Learning from the past

"Since the 2019-20 fires, no fire prevention work has been done with farmers around Budj Bim National Park," Mr Millard said.

"No back-burning , no fuel reduction, and no consultation with landowners - until the fire is already burning.

"Now, with fire within two kilometres of private farmland, authorities have confirmed they will override landowners, cut fences, and do whatever they deem necessary - without speaking to the farmers affected."

Each of Mr Millard's claims has been denied by a Forest Fire Management Victoria spokesperson.

Mr Millard said he also felt like his private land had been used in the past as a containment zone or fire break, without compensation.

"Governments constantly talk about mental health and stress in agriculture - yet expect farmers to endure forced destruction of their land with no consultation or support," he said.

"How can a fifth-generation farmer be expected to cope when he is told that his land, fences, and farming operations are disposable?".

Containing the blaze

Mr Dess said emergency services expected to keep the blaze within park boundaries.

"(The) far south west fire 33 - Budj Bim - Morton Track is currently around 1300 hectares and will increase in size as backburning operations, entirely within the Budj Bim National Park, are undertaken with the intent of containing this fire largely within the boundaries of the Budj Bim National Park," he said.

"Local CFA are providing critical local knowledge to support decision making. The public information team includes community liaison officers that have been active in talking with communities."

Likewise, a CFA spokesperson said it was working with all groups.

"CFA has been made aware of the private owner's concerns and works with local council, other fire agencies and communities to ensure communities are prepared for bushfires," the spokesperson said.

All emergency management operations in Victoria are managed in accordance with the State Emergency Management Priorities.

Forest Fire Management Victoria and CFA crews are currently managing 28 fires which began following multiple bands of lightning since March 9.

Craig Millard is a fifth-generation farmer at Grafton Millard, an historic property located near the Budj Bim National Park. He's afraid of what he'll lose in the latest bushfire which began after a lightning strike on March 9. Picture supplied.

urn:contentItem:6FPD-PGR3-RV4R-61YF-00000-00Mayor urges scrapping levy2025-05-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:20ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 16Mayor urges scrapping levyEddie Russell

Geelong Mayor Stretch Kontelj has written to Premier Jacinta Allan urging her to abandon a controversial new tax that he alleges will cost farmers an extra $1750 a year.

It comes after Mr Kontelj declared that Geelong council would lobby members of the state upper house to stop the tax being introduced.

The proposed Emergency Services and Volunteers Fund, which is on track to replace the Fire Services Property Levy on June 1, will result in Geelong residents coughing up more than $55,000 in 2025-26 - almost $20,000 extra from last financial year.

The extra money will go towards supporting the State Emergency Service (SES), Forest Fire Management Victoria, and the State Control Centre.

The Country Fire Authority (CFA) and Fire Rescue Victoria (FRV) are also included in the fund.

On Tuesday night, Mr Kontelj said the state government was treating councils like "collection agencies" and that local residents did not deserve to be hit with more expenses.

"We advocate on behalf of our community for this tax to be abandoned, in recognition of its significant financial impact on residents and businesses," he said.

"Our ratepayers cannot bear these additional taxes, especially at a time when the cost of living has never been so high." Geelong council claims primary producers will cop a $2800 bill; industrial ratepayers will be slugged a more than $1600 bill; and residents forced to hand over $80 each.

However, a state government spokesman said farmers would only pay $13. Mr Kontelj implored others to protest against the proposed changes. "We encourage ratepayers to join our advocacy, contact their local MPs and share their views on this expanded tax," he said.

Mr Kontelj's letter follows calls for the federal government to reverse funding changes to aged care.

Amendments to the Aged Care Act to be implemented from July 1 would put the council in a "difficult position", Mr Kontelj said.

"Council will be required to find several millions of dollars per annum out of operations to subsidise the ongoing provision of aged care services," he said.

Mr Kontelj said the changes would go against the wishes of the community. "We've heard loud and clear about how much they value our in-home community care service," he said.

"We agree - that's why we're calling on the commonwealth government to commit to aged care by providing the additional funding." Earlier this month, Geelong council was slammed by industry unions and local MPs for planning to cut up to 300 aged care jobs. The future of the in-home community care service is still uncertain, with a decision to be made once consultations finish.

urn:contentItem:6FRK-6WF3-RRN7-150F-00000-00Man arrested after suspicious fires in Shepparton2025-05-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:20ZLexisNexisMan arrested after suspicious fires in Shepparton

Document links may not lead to an active page. Page maintenance is at the discretion of the publisher.

Abby Walter

UPDATED: A Mooroopna man has been arrested after a series of fires were started in bushland near the Midland Highway within two weeks.

Police allege eleven fires were lit in Shepparton and Mooroopna between May 1 and May 12.

The fires impacted numerous plants, trees and grassland, but there were no threats to any properties.

Shepparton Crime Investigation Unit detectives arrested a 76-year-old Mooroopna man on Monday.

He is expected to be charged on summons with lighting the fires.

Police continue to appeal for anyone who witnessed the incident, has CCTV or dashcam footage or information to contact Crime Stoppers on 1800 333 000 or online.

EARLIER

Police are attempting to establish if one or more offenders were involved in lighting at least eight fires in bushland between Shepparton and Mooroopna.

Firefighters from Forest Fire Management Victoria and the CFA were called out to eight blazes between Friday and Monday.

The FFMV units contained fire lit in grass and under trees near the shared bike and pedestrian path between the two towns.

The CFA responded to two incidents were mattresses had been set alight.

Shepparton detectives are investigating the fires with investigators believing an unknown offender or multiple offenders set fire to the bushland.

A Victoria Police spokeswoman said the cause of the fires was being treated as suspicious and investigations remained ongoing.

"Numerous plants, trees and grassland were impacted and there were no threats to any surrounding properties," she said.

"Investigators are working to establish whether the same offender or offenders are responsible for all incidents."

FFMV incident controller Bruce Wehner said there were three fires on Friday, two on Saturday, one on Sunday and another two on Monday in the Shepparton Regional Park.

"All the fires have been ignited close to the shared bike path," he said.

"The biggest one was the first one on Friday which was about 30m by 15m.

"Some were out in the open and some under trees.

"The weather has been pretty kind to us, we've been able to pull them up so they've been burning but we've got to them pretty quick."

Mr Wehner said the CFA was great getting out quickly and knocking fires down with a tanker.

FFMV crews then spent time patrolling and fully extinguishing the fire.

"They're obviously suspicious, there's been no lightning out there in weeks," he said.

"The fire danger at this time of year is pretty low, really, although it is very dry out there.

"You've got the tussock grasses that can be a 1m high but in between them, it's just sort of bare ground and dry leaves.

"For 12 months of the year, you can't light fires like that in the in the forest, unless it's a campfire within the regulations in a pit that's cleared around, and these aren't campfires."

Anyone with information or anyone who may have witnessed any suspicious activity in the area, with dashcam or CCTV footage or information is urged to contact Crime Stoppers on 1800 333 000 or submit a confidential report online at crimestoppersvic.com.au.

urn:contentItem:6FS4-G0R3-RRH7-S566-00000-00Farmers fire up over levy2025-05-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:20ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4Farmers fire up over levyAbby Walter Carly Douglas

Volunteer firefighters and farmers yesterday were preparing to descend on Spring Street in a bid to -extinguish the "unjust" new emergency services tax, while presenting the Allan government with a mock-up bill of more than $1m for the catastrophic Grampians blaze.

Some volunteers are refusing to attend call-outs and have threatened to quit altogether over the new Emergency Services and Volunteers Fund after it was revealed farmers - many of whom are CFA volunteers themselves - could be hardest hit.

In the lead-up to the return of parliament next week, senior volunteer firefighters have sent out a call to action, -encouraging fuming farmers and firefighters to join a demonstration at Spring Street on Friday morning.

One rally organiser, who did not want his name published, told the Herald Sun it was "time to be seen".

"This tax is a joke," he said.

The new charge, which will replace the current Fire Services Levy, has also caused a stir among members of the CFA Westmere Group brigades in Victoria's fire-prone west.

In a letter to Emergency Services Minister Vicki Ward, farmer and CFA volunteer Pat Millear calculated what the cost to the state of fighting the summer's devastating Grampians fires - which burnt land the size of Singapore - would have been without volunteers.

His "bill" included $540,000 for tankers manned by an -average of four CFA volunteers for 10 days, another $500,000 for 50 private water tankers, and $37,500 for five volunteers to staff the Willaura local command facility.

Mr Millear said farmers -already faced drought, cost-of-living pressures and mental health challenges, and the "unjust" tax would exacerbate their stress and only reduce CFA volunteer numbers.

Senior Toolleen brigade member Andrew, who has volunteered for the CFA for more than 20 years, said he was no longer attending call-outs -because of the proposed tax change. "It's a tax grab," he said. "The state government have mismanaged their own finances and now they're coming after us." Last year Victorians paid $602m through the Fire Services Levy on residential, industrial, commercial and primary production land.

Under the proposed increase, based on capital improved value in 2024, Victorians will pay $1.2bn to the fund. About $205m of that will come from farmers.

The state government said the increase for the average farm was $13 a week, and that active volunteers and life members of VICSES and CFA were exempt from the levy "in recognition of the work they do to keep us all safe".

"We'll continue to work to pass these changes, because this legislation will give our volunteers and emergency services the tools and resources they need to keep communities safe and save lives," the spokesman said Volunteers, however, will have to apply for a rebate on the tax, which will apply to farmland or single farm enterprises.

Revenue from the new tax is intended to fund up to 95 per cent of the budgets for Victoria SES, triple-0, the State Control Centre, Emergency Management Victoria, Emergency Recovery Victoria, and Forest Fire Management Victoria. abby.walter@news.com.au

urn:contentItem:6F0N-P753-RVBC-S3VH-00000-00Wimmera community united as Little Desert National Park bushfire continues2025-01-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:20ZLexisNexisWimmera community united as Little Desert National Park bushfire continuesBen Fraser, Sheryl Lowe, Lucas Holmes & John Hall

A bushfire razed more than 65,000 hectares in northwest Wimmera.

A relentless bushfire has torn through more than 65,000 hectares in northwest Wimmera, razing landmarks and forcing hundreds to flee in less than 24 hours.

It is understood that at least one building - the popular Little Desert Nature Lodge - has been destroyed after the blaze ignited at 1.30pm on Monday, January 27, about 15km north of Goroke.

Strong winds accelerated the firefront through Little Desert National Park before it reached the outskirts of Dimboola just six hours later.

"The fire grew to such a size and was carrying such energy with it yesterday that it made it quite difficult for any containment to occur," State Control Centre spokesperson Luke Heagerty told AAP.

Residents were told to leave the area and then seek shelter as fire crews battled the blaze overnight.

Evacuation centres opened in Dimboola, Warracknabeal and Horsham to accommodate displaced residents.

A spokesperson from the Salvation Army said they served 75 people for breakfast in Horsham.

Chan Uoy, the Hindmarsh Shire Council deputy mayor and owner of the Dimboola Imaginarium, was at the Horsham Relief Centre after evacuating on Monday.

"The text came through at 6.57pm saying we have half an hour to evacuate, but it was the smoke and the smell of it that made it seem real," he said.

"It was a very surreal experience. As we got into our vehicles to leave, seeing the stream of cars leaving Dimboola was again a reality check that this was really happening."

Mr Uoy said he was impressed by the resolve of the community.

"The thing that impressed me the most has been the solidarity of people," he said.

"People you have never spoken to are now chatting together. We are all in the same situation, and I think this makes us stronger."

Dimboola Football Netball Club president Hayden Eldridge was one of a handful of people who stayed.

"I would have said that 90 per cent of the town evacuated," he said.

"A few of us that know the area a little bit hung back to see what we could help."

Mr Eldridge said emergency services set up a base of operations at the club rooms.

"We've set up a base here because it's probably a safe zone at this stage," he said.

"We've got the [fire crews here], they got the facilities, toilets, they can have a feed.

"We've got barbecues set up, fridges for cold drinks, doing coffee... all the volunteer work for the fireies themselves."

Dimboola Golf Club chef Cat Clark was eager to know how things were looking after she evacuated to Warracknabeal.

"I'm just ready to find out how everything's kind of looking ... It's just that waiting game to get home to check it all out," she said.

As warnings began coming through the VicEmergency app, Ms Clarke headed to her restaurant at the Dimboola Golf Club.

"On the way out there, you could just see the smoke, and the wind was just vile; it was changing direction, left, right and centre, and you could see the smoke coming in."

Ms Clarke returned home, making sure her elderly neighbours were prepared to evacuate.

"The convoy of the Dimboola township was on their way through there [to Warracknabeal]."

Ms Clarke helped her neighbours find a motel and headed for a friend's place.

Having evacuated Dimboola, Ms Clarke was struck by the generosity and community support the people from Dimboola were seeing.

It is understood dry lightning ignited several blazes across the region.

There were at least four fires in the Grampians National Park, with the most serious just near a popular campground near Victoria Valley.

The Western Highway is closed between Horsham and Dimboola and Dimboola and Nhill.

A bushfire ignited by dry lightning has burnt more than 63,000ha. Picture supplied by Forest Fire Management Victoria

urn:contentItem:6F0N-P753-RVBC-S3VS-00000-00Relief in sight for Dimboola residents, Grampians fire could burn for weeks2025-01-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:20ZLexisNexisRelief in sight for Dimboola residents, Grampians fire could burn for weeksBen Fraser

Emergency services provide updates on Wimmera, Grampians bushfires.

Dimboola residents could be allowed to return to their homes today as emergency services battle to gain an upper hand in the Little Desert National Park Bushfire.

Emergency Management Commissioner Rick Nugent said he expected advice to be downgraded after career and volunteer firefighters reduce the threat to the Wimmera township.

"The emergency warning for Dimboola is expected to be downgraded shortly to 'Safe to return'... we're just finalizing those arrangements," he said.

"I'd sincerely like to thank the community for actively monitoring conditions and listening to the advice provided.

"I'm incredibly thankful ... that no lives have been lost from this fire, and we have no reports of injuries either."

The Commissioner said the bushfire's spread was "incredibly fast," with 14-18km/h speeds helping it burn more than 63,000ha of land.

"We saw hot temperatures [on Monday] with strong north, northwesterly winds with gusts of up to 70km/h, particularly in the west of the state," he said.

"This was followed by a cool change with south-southwesterly winds and gusty conditions that moved across the state into last night."

He confirmed the Little Desert Nature Lodge was destroyed, while another two farmhouses are being assessed for damage.

Commissioner Nugent said an estimated 10,000 dry lightning strikes occurred in Victoria on January 27, resulting in multiple ignitions across the state.

"The very dry conditions and high fuel loads we have resulted in a number of fires," he said.

"There [were] around 60 to 70 new fire started in private lands, and around 80 fire starts in public lands and national parks."

Grampians bushfires continue to grow in unburnt areas

Five blazes continue to burn in the Grampians National Park, with three in the north and two in the south.

He said authorities believe the fires would join in the coming days.

"Five fires started by lightning strikes around 5-6pm yesterday; three of those in the northwestern part of the Grampians, and two in the southwestern part," Commissioner Nugent said.

"These files continue to grow in will continue to grow in size and will burn for some time.

"They'll be incredibly challenging for firefighters to contain that fire."

Forest Fire Management Victoria Chief Fire Officer Chris Hardman said the remoteness of the new fires was making it difficult for firefighters to reach them.

"Two of those [fires] are in the southwestern, unburnt part of the Grampians, and three in the northwestern unburnt part," he said.

"Those fires will continue to grow, and they will become what we would describe as a campaign fire.

"Those fires in the southern part of the Grampians will progress and eventually meet up with those fires in the northern parts.

"I just want to create an expectation that these fires will be in play for some time."

He said the Wartook and Halls Gap communities should monitor the fires throughout the week.

"Firefighters are planning to do everything in their power to protect the communities of Wartook and Halls Gap from the progression of this fire over the coming days," Mr Hardman said.

"That will mean that decisions around the closure of the park will be made at various times.

"We're not looking at evacuating Halls Gap at this stage, but certainly access into Halls Gap from the Grampians road will be available for an undefined period."

The public can no longer Halls Gap via Mount Victory Road as firefighters access the blazes.

A community meeting will be held at the Laharum Recreation Reserve from 6pm on Tuesday, January 28, to provide up-to-date information about the fires.

Career and volunteer firefighters fought the Little Desert National Park bushfire throughout the night. Picture supplied by Forest Fire Management Victoria

Career and volunteer firefighters fought the Little Desert National Park bushfire throughout the night. Picture supplied by Forest Fire Management Victoria

Career and volunteer firefighters fought the Little Desert National Park bushfire throughout the night. Picture supplied by Forest Fire Management Victoria

urn:contentItem:6FP8-D613-SBFD-D42M-00000-00Stretch's $25m question to the Premier2025-04-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:20ZLexisNexisStretch's $25m question to the Premier

Document links may not lead to an active page. Page maintenance is at the discretion of the publisher.

Eddie Russell

Surf Coast Shire councillors have joined Geelong mayor Stretch Kontelj in demanding the Premier abandon a controversial new tax that will allegedly cost the region's ratepayers almost $25m extra a year.

On Tuesday, Mr Kontelj wrote to Jacinta Allan urging her to abandon the proposed Emergency Services and Volunteers Fund, which is set to replace the Fire Services Levy on June 1.

According to Geelong council, residents will now have to cough up $55m in 2025-26 - a drastic increase compared to the $36m paid last financial year.

On top of that, the state government's coffers will be boosted an additional $5m by Surf Coast residents.

The extra money will go towards supporting the State Emergency Service (SES), Forest Fire Management Victoria, and the State Control Centre.

The Country Fire Authority (CFA) and Fire Rescue Victoria (FRV) are also included in the fund.

Mr Kontelj said that it was an inappropriate time to slug locals with more expenses.

"We advocate on behalf of our community for this tax to be abandoned, in recognition of its significant financial impact on residents and businesses," he said.

"Our ratepayers cannot bear these additional taxes, especially at a time when cost of living has never been so high."

Calculations conducted by Geelong council indicate primary producers will cop a $2800 bill (a $1700 increase); industrial ratepayers more than $1600 (a $500 increase); and residents $80 each.

However, a state government spokesman said that farmers would only pay $13.

Mr Kontelj implored others to protest the proposed changes.

"We encourage ratepayers to join our advocacy, contact their local MPs and share their views on this expanded tax."

In a meeting on Tuesday night, Surf Coast councillors agreed to write to the Premier and key government ministers in opposition.

They will argue for the levy to be scrapped; or, failing that, a guarantee that funds collected be invested directly back into the area.

Surf Coast mayor Mike Bodsworth said that the agricultural community would be hit hardest.

"The levy would mean increased costs across all property types, but the biggest impact would be on our farmers," he said.

"It would place an unfair and substantial burden on primary production land owners at a time when they're already under financial pressure as a result of the drought."

Mr Bodsworth also pointed out the tax would place an unnecessary administrative burden on the council.

"Not only will this method place a heavy strain on Council resources, it will no doubt also be seen by many ratepayers as a Council fee, resulting in reputational damage."

urn:contentItem:6FYB-26G3-S0RY-Y51T-00000-00Revealed: figures show the real reason for $7 billion levy2025-06-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:20ZLexisNexisNEWS3Revealed: figures show the real reason for $7 billion levyBen Silvester

The CFA and VICSES will receive only a small fraction of funds.

More than half of the $7 billion collected in the government's Emergency Services and Volunteer Fund over the next four years will be sucked up by employee costs for Victoria's paid firefighters, new figures show.

The controversial new levy has been spruiked by the government as a lifeline for Victoria's volunteer emergency services - the CFA and VICSES - but only a tiny share will go to the volunteers.

Analysis by ACM - publisher of the Bendigo Advertiser - reveals Fire Rescue Victoria will consume up to 70 per cent of the funding each year.

The figures also showed FRV's costs were rising so quickly that the government may not be able to deliver its funding promises to the three agencies under the levy.

Victoria's Fire Services Levy is changing into the Emergency Services and Volunteers Fund on July 1.

All ratepayers will pay substantially more under the new levy , which aims to raise $7 billion over the next four years, or $2.9 billion more than the previous levy would have. It is due to collect $1.62 billion in 2025-26 and $1.8 billion in each of the next three years. Victoria's farmers were due to carry the heaviest burden under the new system, with many facing double or triple the previous levy.

But Premier Jacinta Allan announced a one-year reprieve for primary producers on Friday, with farmers allowed to pay the old rate for the 2025-26 financial year. The new levy has been politically toxic for the government , triggering protests both on the steps of parliament and across the state.

But the government persisted with the plan and pushed the levy through parliament, despite the blowback.

The government has sold the new levy as "equipping our emergency services for the future".

Treasurer Jaclyn Symes has promised every cent will go into emergency services.

"These changes will give emergency services the funding and equipment they need as they face natural disasters which are happening more often and becoming more destructive."

Emergency Services Minister Vicki Ward also stressed the "modern equipment" the new fund would provide.

The government announced $406 million in new funding over five years for emergency services in the 2025 budget and 2024 mid-year budget update.

This funding includes $110 million for new trucks for the CFA, FRV and VICSES, but it's unclear whether it will be funded through the new levy.

But this funding would represent barely 5 per cent of the revenue raised by the levy.

On the other hand, the government has promised 95 per cent of CFA and VICSES's budgets will come from the levy, as well as 90 per cent of FRV's funding.

An analysis of these budgets showed this was a huge amount of money, so much money that it would suck up the majority of the levy funds. In 2023-24, the government provided $1.07 billion in grant funding to FRV, with the agency also recording a $101 million deficit. In 2023-24, the CFA received $342 million in grant funding and VICSES received $86 million.

That makes a total of $1.5 billion for the three agencies, with FRV making up more than 70 per cent.

But those were the grant costs in 2023-24, so what are they likely to be in 2025-26, the first year of the levy?

CFA and VICSES funding has only grown minimally over the past few years, and the government has given no indication of a rise in grant funding, so it is likely they will be about $350 million and $90 million.

But FRV's costs have risen hugely since the organisation was founded in 2020. On average, they have risen by $100 million every year. If they keep rising at the same rate, FRV's grant funding could be close to $1.3 billion in 2025-26.

If the government provides 90 per cent of this funding from the levy, that would be more than $1.15 billion.

The new levy was only projected to raise $1.62 billion in 2025-26, meaning FRV would soak up 70 per cent of the money.

This would leave barely enough for the promised CFA and VICSES funding, let alone other services like Triple Zero Victoria, Emergency Management Victoria and Forest Fire Management Victoria, which are also supposed to be funded through the levy.

The government told ACM there was "sufficient forecast revenue" to cover the promised costs.

Victorian Nationals leader and opposition emergency services spokesperson Danny O'Brien said the figures showed the levy was just a cost-shifting exercise.

"Labor needs to explain in detail whether our emergency services are actually getting any benefit from a $3 billion new tax."

Premier Jacinta Allan at last week's announcement. Picture by Lachlan Bence
