urn:contentItem:6G34-44G3-RS9J-S3B0-00000-00Why Queensland should be on your holiday list this winter2025-06-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:20ZLexisNexisWhy Queensland should be on your holiday list this winter

Document links may not lead to an active page. Page maintenance is at the discretion of the publisher.

STAFF AND CONTRIBUTORS

Queensland is an obvious choice when it comes to escaping the cold weather. Head north for tropical warmth or immerse yourself in some of the state's cooler climes.

Brisbane

It's manta ray season all year long in the waters surrounding Lady Elliot Island but it reaches fever pitch in winter. For those pressed for time, Emporium South Bank in Brisbane offers the chance to snorkel with squadrons of the graceful giants, wrapped up in a two-night Reef & Retreat getaway. Pairing a pampered stay at the hotel, guests are then flown to the eco island resort for an action-packed day, with glass-bottom boat tour, guided snorkelling, fish feeding and a tropical buffet lunch.

When the British & Irish Lions descend on Brisbane for two matches (July 2 and 19), guests at the new Queens Wharf Residences will have their home away from home sorted. There are more than 200 well-appointed apartments in the tallest tower of the Queen's Wharf Precinct, delivering river and botanic garden views, plus in-room amenities by Elysia Wellness Retreat. Footy fever or not, it makes for a chic city stay, with a new public art trail to wander, a wine lounge, sauna and steam room.

Tropical North QLD

Swap the southern chill for the swaying palms and lagoon pools of the Sheraton Grand Mirage in Port Douglas, home base for Australia's premier tropical food festival. At Taste Port Douglas (August 7-10), guests can mingle with master chefs, join cooking classes and walk off indulgent meals along golden sands. Highlights include the Long Lunch series beneath the sprawling canopies of poinciana trees in Market Park, and the theatrical Flames of the Forest fire show set deep in the Daintree Rainforest. Festival packages are available.

After three seasons in the Med, the 41m Benetti superyacht MY Northern Escape has been relocated to Cairns. During the winter months, migrating dwarf minke and humpback whales add an extra layer of excitement to tailored itineraries. Most requested is a five- to seven-night journey from Cairns to Lizard Island, with stops to dive or snorkel the Ribbon Reefs. Or kick things up a notch with the new Outback to Ocean package, connecting Luxury Lodges of Australia member Mt Mulligan Lodge with a bespoke Morris Nautical Charter and a stay at Orpheus Island resort or the ultra-private and chic house on Pelorus Island.

Gold Coast Hinterland

It's hard to think of an Australian hot tub with a more surprising view than that of the one cleverly perched at the edge of Verandah House Country Estate, Mount Tamborine. The cedar tub offers not only a magnesium soak but a glimpse of distant Gold Coast skyscrapers. Life here is a world away from the Glitter Strip. Think cheeky king parrots eyeing your breakfast, crackling in-room fireplaces and an onsite barrel sauna. It's enough to attract celebrity guests such as actor Jude Law.

Scenic Rim

Just over an hour's drive from Brisbane, Spicers Hidden Vale is well known among foodies. They flock to the rural retreat's Homage restaurant for languid lunches starring local ingredients such as Marburg emu and Toowoomba beef (request a table on the deck with its striking views overlooking the infinity pool and mango tree). Fully relax by overnighting in a heritage cottage or contemporary cabin with a soaring stone fireplace and outdoor bath on a secluded deck. Say hi to the kangaroos that pop by to graze the lawns.

Sunshine Coast Hinterland

On a working farm in Kin Kin, Mayan Farm pairs pastoral charm with quiet luxury just 40 minutes from Noosa. Four new rammed-earth villas sit gently on the land, two with outdoor spas, two welcoming pets, all with views that overlook Kin Kin Creek and tucked away from the bite of westerly winds. Days unfold slowly here: a pottery class, horse riding, perhaps a long lunch prepared by a private chef. As evening falls, smoke drifts from the outdoor kitchen with six grills and a pizza oven.

K'gari/Fraser Island

Winter on the Fraser Coast brings a rare kind of magic. Migrating humpback whales don't simply cruise by; they stay and play in the warm waters of Hervey Bay. From mid-July to late October, Fraser Island Boat Charters offers private, skippered multi-day sailings aboard luxury catamaran K'gari Breeze, with tailored itineraries and seafood caught fresh each day. Guests can expect up-close encounters with the cetaceans, the chance to swim alongside them, and to be lulled to sleep by their songs captured by the onboard hydraphone.

Magnetic Island

It's always summer on Magnetic, the modest Queensland island off the Townsville coast where national park meets the Great Barrier Reef. Balmy winters signal the onset of whale season - watch them fluking from the beach at Geoffrey Bay - but koalas, rock wallabies and rich birdlife are year-round attractions. Choose from two dozen beaches, four towns, myriad hiking trails and watersport options including half and full-day outings aboard the sailing yacht Pilgrim. To stay, Best of Magnetic has a choice selection of villas, apartments and houses.

Torres Strait

It's just a two-hour flight from Cairns but Horn Island, entry point to the vast Torres Strait archipelago in our far north, feels a world away from the rest of Australia. Base yourself on nearby Thursday Island/Waiben, home to the Gab Titui Cultural Centre, military sights and the nation's most northerly pub. For lofty views take a scenic heli flight with Nautilus Aviation over the tip of the continent. Strait Experience can organise one to three-day ­adventurous itineraries ex-Cairns. Stay at the self-catering Island Villas.

NORTHERN TERRITORY

Uluru

Running anywhere in the red centre in summer is unthinkable. In July, however, when average daily temperatures hover around 18C, dipping close to zero overnight, jogging becomes a much more palatable proposition. The Australian Outback Marathon attracts runners to the nation's spiritual heart on July 26 for an event that features full and half marathons plus 11km and 6km fun runs. Routes traverse red dirt tracks, unsealed roads and sand dunes, and whether you're a spectator or a participant, the scenery promises to be spectacular. Ayers Rock Resort has a range of accommodation to suit all budgets. Our pick? Sails in the Desert with its grove of silvery gums and Ilkari restaurant.

For winter getaways in NSW and South Australia, click here.

Contributors: Penny Hunter, Celeste Mitchell, Kendall Hill, Ricky French, Katrina Lobley.

If you love to travel, sign up to our free weekly Travel + Luxury newsletter here.

urn:contentItem:6FS4-G0R3-RRPG-2010-00000-00Firefighting words as farmers protest levy2025-05-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:20ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4Firefighting words as farmers protest levyAbby Walter Carly Douglas

Volunteer firefighters and farmers yesterday were preparing to descend on Spring Street in a bid to -extinguish the "unjust" new emergency services tax, while presenting the Allan government with a mock-up bill of more than $1m for the catastrophic Grampians blaze.

Some volunteers are refusing to attend call-outs and have threatened to quit altogether over the new Emergency Services and Volunteers Fund after it was revealed farmers - many of whom are CFA volunteers themselves - could be hardest hit.

In the lead-up to the return of parliament next week, senior volunteer firefighters have sent out a call to action, -encouraging fuming farmers and firefighters to join a demonstration at Spring Street on Friday morning.

One rally organiser, who did not want his name published, told the Herald Sun it was "time to be seen".

"This tax is a joke," he said.

The new charge, which will replace the current Fire Services Levy, has also caused a stir among members of the CFA Westmere Group brigades in Victoria's fire-prone west.

In a letter to Emergency Services Minister Vicki Ward, farmer and CFA volunteer Pat Millear calculated what the cost to the state of fighting the summer's devastating Grampians fires - which burnt land the size of Singapore - would have been without volunteers.

His "bill" included $540,000 for tankers manned by an -average of four CFA volunteers for 10 days, another $500,000 for 50 private water tankers, and $37,500 for five volunteers to staff the Willaura local command facility.

Mr Millear said farmers -already faced drought, cost-of-living pressures and mental health challenges, and the "unjust" tax would exacerbate their stress and only reduce CFA volunteer numbers.

"It is critical to explore alternative funding mechanisms that do not place an undue burden on the very volunteers who protect our state," Mr Millear said.

Senior Toolleen brigade member Andrew, who has volunteered for the CFA for more than 20 years, said he was no longer attending call-outs -because of the proposed tax change.

"It's a tax grab," he said.

"The state government have mismanaged their own finances and now they're coming after us." Last year Victorians paid $602m through the Fire Services Levy on residential, industrial, commercial and primary production land.

Under the proposed increase, based on capital improved value in 2024, Victorians will pay $1.2bn to the fund. About $205m of that will come from farmers.

The state government said the increase for the average farm was $13 a week, and that active volunteers and life members of VICSES and CFA were exempt from the levy "in recognition of the work they do to keep us all safe".

"We'll continue to work to pass these changes, because this legislation will give our volunteers and emergency services the tools and resources they need to keep communities safe and save lives," the spokesman said Volunteers, however, will have to apply for a rebate on the tax, which will apply to farmland or single farm enterprises. VICSES and CFA volunteers and life members will be eligible for a rebate on their primary places of residence or farms, capped to the value of a $5m farm.

Revenue from the new tax is intended to fund up to 95 per cent of the budgets for Victoria SES, triple-0, the State Control Centre, Emergency Management Victoria, Emergency Recovery Victoria, and Forest Fire Management Victoria.

abby.walter@news.com.au

urn:contentItem:6FP9-18B3-RRVV-V2M5-00000-00Don't be left red-faced by fire, CFA warns2025-05-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:20ZLexisNexisNEWS7Don't be left red-faced by fire, CFA warnsSophie Else

'It's all about remaining vigilant ... don't be complacent.'

With the end of the fire danger period and the easing of fire restrictions, Border residents are being urged to take extra care when burning off.

The Country Fire Authority warns the risk of burn-offs escaping remains high in the coming weeks.

Although fire restrictions are being lifted in Wodonga, Indigo and Alpine municipalities from today, District 24 assistant chief fire officer Brett Myers said now was not the time to be complacent.

He said the current level of dryness, lack of rainfall and wind could create the potential for fires to spread quite rapidly, especially in grasslands. The CFA expected the grassfire risk to remain across Victoria and asked people to remain alert and prepared.

"The last six to eight weeks CFA, along with local government and forest fire management, have been meeting to ascertain when is the right timing to remove the fire danger restrictions," Mr Myers said.

"Prevailing dryness and a lack of rainfall in Towong Shire has led to an elevated risk right across that geographical area. The fire danger period and fire restrictions will remain in place until May 26 for all locations in Towong. Unless we receive substantial rain between now and then, that time frame may even push out further.

He said April and May 2024 proved the "busiest months of the year" for the CFA brigades.

"Predominantly because people were lighting up their burn-off piles on their property and not understanding the risk of that fire spreading quite quickly with minimal wind," he said.

Landowners could take precautions to further reduce the risk when carrying out a burn on their property. These included checking the council's regulations about when and where burning off is permitted, monitoring the weather conditions, ensuring an adequate water supply, cleaning up the perimeter of the burn site beforehand, registering the burn-off, notifying neighbours, and making sure the fire is fully extinguished afterwards.

Mr Myers said it was important to do a mineral earth line around the burn-off, which would prevent the fire from spreading further by removing the fuel.

"It is quite complacent for people to light a fire and then walk away and leave it. Before you know it, it's spread into areas that weren't intended to be burnt and potentially causing devastation," he said.

"It's all about remaining vigilant. Controlling a fire on your property is your responsibility. It could be quite an embarrassing phone call to triple zero to request assistance for an out of control fire that you have inadvertently created."

CFA District 24 assistant chief fire officer Brett Myers says people need to be more vigilant when it comes to burning off, especially with fire restrictions lifting from today. Pictures by Phoebe Adams

urn:contentItem:6FVJ-DWM3-RTBY-G2B9-00000-00Weak state budget for agriculture sees little boost for Victoria's farmers2025-05-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:20ZLexisNexisWeak state budget for agriculture sees little boost for Victoria's farmersBarry Murphy

Funding was directed at disease control and climate change.

A weak state budget for agriculture is set to see little boost for Victoria's farmers.

Treasurer Jaclyn Symes has announced new funding of just $36.6 million for the state's $20 billion farm sector in the 2025/26 budget.

The majority of this funding will be directed into biosecurity and disease control and supporting farmers as they adapt to the challenges of climate change.

A total of $6.1m will be spent on such climate change initiatives, with the exact parameters and reach of the funding yet to specified.

The state will spend approximately $7.6m next year on extra resourcing and equipment to make sure Agriculture Victoria is ready to respond to future biosecurity emergencies, such as further avian influenza outbreaks .

A further $9m has been allocated to cover the work of animal welfare organisations, including the work of the RSPCA Inspectorate on behalf of the state.

This will include the inspection and regulation of dog breeders, for example, an area under the remit of Agriculture Victoria.

The budget provides $11.3m for pest control over the next year, with $2.1m of this to be spent on the continuation of Victoria's Fox Bounty.

The remaining $9.2m will be spent on the control of other pests such as deer, feral cats, foxes and pigs.

However, there will be no new funding for the control of wild dogs, an issue affecting producers across much of the state at present.

In contrast, $400,000 is budgeted for the development of a new hemp industry, including the cost of forming legislation to bolster the sector.

Farmers unable to farm sheep due to growing wild dog numbers could get into hemp farming, perhaps.

The budget invests $1.2m to encourage more women into leadership in agriculture.

The budget announcement does not include the $15.9m announced on Friday for additional support for drought-hit farmers, nor the $900,000 also announced then for the National Centre for Farmer Health.

Agriculture Minister Ros Spence said the budget was aimed where farmers needed it most.

"Victorian farmers supply the fresh food and produce that feeds our state and beyond," she said.

"This budget protects them from biosecurity threats and diseases, helping them grow and adapt to our changing climate."

Overall, the Department of Energy, Environment and Climate Action (DEECA), in which Agriculture Victoria sits, is budgeted to spend $2.65bn for the financial year 2025/26.

This is up about $200m on the $2.45bn budgeted for 2024/25.

Within the DEECA budget, agriculture has been projected to have a total output of $537.2m for 2025/26.

Of other benefit to rural and regional Victorians, Tuesday's budget allocated $967m in total investment to fix potholes and resurface roads across the state.

The funding will see the rehabilitation of the San Remo Bridge connecting Philip Island to the mainland.

It will also be spent on strengthening the Mt Emu Creek Bridge on the Princes Highway West in Terang to accommodate high-productivity freight vehicles.

There will also be saftey upgrades on the Princes Highway East in Lakes Entrance.

Elsewhere, Forest Fire Management Victoria is set to get a funding boost.

With an allocated $23.5m, it will complete planned burns and other critical fuel management to lower bushfire risk.

The budget also invests $21.1m to protect state parks, forests and beaches.

Within this, $17.3m will go toward Landcare and Coastcare projects to care for the bush and beaches.

The additional $3.8m will be spent on creating and maintaining 'Liwik Barring', a wildlife habitat which spans through parts of the farmland in the Yarra Valley and Dandenong ranges.

Premier Jacinta Allan said the budget was "focused on what matters most" and highlighted some of the measures to support families struggling with the high cost of living.

Public transport will be made free for all those under 18 years old across the state.

The same provision will be made for seniors at weekends, anywhere in the state.

Treasurer Jaclyn Symes announced her state Budget 2025/26 on Tuesday in Melbourne. Picture by Barry Murphy

urn:contentItem:6DP4-F6N3-RSRT-C18H-00000-00How this new building could help save your life, or your home, during a bushfire2024-12-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:20ZLexisNexisHow this new building could help save your life, or your home, during a bushfireAdam Spencer

It's in full swing today with the sweltering weather.

A brand new purpose-built facility for authorities to co-ordinate responses to bushfires and other emergencies is already buzzing as the Ballarat region deals with its hottest December day since 2019 .

The Forest Fire Management Victoria Incident Control Centre at Mount Rowan is fully operational and replaces the ICC in Sebastopol which has been operating for decades. It is one of 40 ICCs across Victoria.

The centre will be used by the CFA, Fire Rescue Victoria, the SES, Victoria Police, councils, government and other agencies during emergencies such as bushfires, storms or floods.

The facility includes a large "map room" featuring large screens that can display maps, weather, the status of pre-determined dispatch for firefighting aircraft , live TV broadcasts and virtually anything else staff need to co-ordinate a response.

It also features a separate aircraft communication room, a separate radio room and areas for other agencies to work.

"It's a purpose-built facility that is just state of the art in terms of emergency response," Forest Fire Management Victoria Deputy Chief Fire Officer, Grampians Region, Jason Hellyer said.

"We bring people in from all over the state ... they need to be able to come in and 'plug and play' in terms of what they need."

Another benefit of the new building is it is less than one kilometre from the Western Freeway, improving access to fires and other emergency incidents.

"What we've been finding with fires and emergencies over recent times is the more we collaborate and understand how we work together the quicker we can respond and get on top of emergencies," FFMV Midlands District Manager Dave Watson said.

"The Ballarat incident control centre is one of two in the Grampians region; it goes up to Beaufort, goes to Daylesford, Hepburn Springs, Trentham, down to Bacchus Marsh, and across through Cressy and Lake Bolac.

"It picks up some really important communities and a lot of the population."

The facility was put through its paces a couple of weeks ago when all agencies came together for a testing day in preparation for summer and another potentially dangerous fire season.

urn:contentItem:6F8S-KG43-RWNY-0482-00000-00Mt Buninyong fire likely to 'burn for some days' as investigation continues2025-03-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:20ZLexisNexisSaturdayMt Buninyong fire likely to 'burn for some days' as investigation continuesMichelle Smith

Three firefighters were injured while tackling the blaze.

Three firefighters were injured fighting to contain the Mount Buninyong fire, with the bushfire likely to continue to "burn for some days".

Access to the top of the mountain will remain closed as firefighters battle to extinguish the blaze which has been burning since Wednesday.

With no rain forecast, Ballarat incident controller Lachlan Redman said the fire would be difficult to fully extinguish.

"You can appreciate with a grass and scrub fire of this size, it's very difficult to put out without some rain to assist and the weather conditions, unfortunately for us, have presented an unprecedented dry season. That means dry fuels, and that means it doesn't take much at all for a fire to take off," Mr Redman told a community meeting in Buninyong late Thursday.

"You will see a presence of both CFA and Forest Fire Management Victoria employees here at the scene for the coming days until this fire is fully extinguished."

The blaze has burned more than 51 hectares of Mount Buninyong and was declared contained late on Thursday.

"This fire will continue to burn for some days within that containment though," Mr Redman said.

Three firefighters were injured, either from heat exhaustion or smoke inhalation, while fighting the blaze.

The cause of the fire has not yet been determined and is under investigation by Victoria Police.

Mr Redman said the perimeter of the fire was about five kilometres and aircraft had been critical in helping douse the blaze.

"It's very challenging in terms of access and egress for our firefighters and our control strategy, part of, is allowing the fire to come out to those containment lines but also suppression efforts from ground crews and (using) our aircraft firefighting capability," he said.

Buninyong Police Station officer in charge Peter Anderson also spoke at the meeting, saying road closures would remain in place over the coming days.

Yendon No. 2 Rd remains closed from the Midland Highway to Wiggins Road, as does Mount Buninyong Road from Blackberry Lane to the top of the mountain.

The Mount Buninyong walking track is also closed.

"Closures will stay in place for the foreseeable future due to dangerous trees and hazardous conditions," Sgt Anderson said.

Residents who evacuated have been allowed to return to their homes and there has been no loss of "infrastructure or assets" as a result of the fire.

Mr Redman said, based on forecasts, he was not expecting any further increase in fire activity but smoke would remain visible.

Police are investigating the cause of the Mount Buninyong blaze and of a nearby fire at Boak Road, Mount Clear, which broke out shortly after.

About 12.45pm on Friday the previous Boak Rd fire reignited but was quickly controlled by Forest Fire Management Victoria firefighters and CFA crews.

urn:contentItem:6DYK-VDP3-RRXJ-155V-00000-00Campers spark bushfire2025-01-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:20ZLexisNexisNEWS10Campers spark bushfire

PRINT ONLY COPY

Halls Gap residents were on edge again after another bushfire started near the tourist town.

However, Forest Fire Management Victoria chief fire officer Chris Hardman says this time, it could be due to "irresponsible" campers.

"I'm really disappointed to see we have a fire just two kilometres north of Halls Gap," he said. "This fire was most likely caused by campers or people who lit a fire over the railing on the edge of the Boroka Lookout. This community has been through enough."

Mr Hardman urged anyone with information regarding the fire, which ignited late on Sunday night and slowly burnt at least seven hectares, to contact the police immediately.

"We will do our best to contain this fire and protect the community."

The bushfire is believed to have started before 10pm on January 19.

Forest Fire Management Victoria crews worked around the clock to contain the fire on Boroka Track.

Firefighters from around the region battled the blaze from the ground while crews water-bombed the out-of-control bushfire just one kilometre north of Halls Gap.

As the fire moved south towards the Wonderland area, a 'Watch and Act: Leave Now' warning was issued for people on the Grampians Peak Trail.

The blaze was declared contained at 10am on January 21; but the Boroka Track area was deemed unsafe.

Check the VicTraffic website (www.traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for updates on road closures.

Water bombers operated throughout the night to bring the Boroka Lookout bushfire under control. Picture supplied by Karl Meyer

urn:contentItem:6DY5-WVR3-RRW4-416S-00000-00Farmers and CFA volunteers say green agenda worsened Grampian bushfires2025-01-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:20ZLexisNexisFarmers and CFA volunteers say green agenda worsened Grampian bushfiresBarry Murphy

Willaura farmers were left battling the flames over Christmas.

Farmers and Country Fire Authority volunteers have warned that the government's green agenda worsened the extent and impact of the recent Grampians bushfires.

They feel a lack of a "common sense" approach to forest fire management and prevention meant more wildlife were lost and extra farmland was burned.

Westmere Fire Brigades group officer Pat Millear, Willaura, heads up a team of 18 brigades which protect 400,000 hectares, east of the Grampians.

He is also captain of his own local Willaura CFA and shares the views of his fellow volunteers.

The sheep farmer said the Forest Fire Management (FFM) team for the Grampians have a plan for proper bushfire prevention in the state park and need to be allowed to implement it.

Mr Millear warned that nothing has been learned since the Mount Lubra fires in January 2006 which saw 47 per cent of the Grampians National Park burn.

"Forest Fire Management have been trying to manage [prevention] as best they can," he said.

"But since the Mount Lubra fire in 2006, the green movement is obviously holding them back from burning or putting in strategic breaks which they want to do.

"They're fighting them because they don't want them burning more than they have to, knocking over trees or building in containment lines.

"We all feel that they have to build bigger containment lines.

"The government has got to come in and just oversee this and be really strong.

"If this is forest management, it's not working."

Mr Millear suggested that the green agenda preventing FFM from putting in proper fire breaks has meant more wildlife and forest has been lost .

"It's been burnt twice now inside 20 years and the wildlife that's been lost has been so significant," he said.

"We're just lucky we didn't lose any lives in this one."

Mr Millear said the same issue was arising across Victoria's state lands and forests and going forward, the government needed to listen to those in these rural areas.

"Local knowledge is second to none and if they just listened to us, it could help people understand more," he said.

He said if fire breaks weren't put in going forward, the same situation would be repeated, where a Grampians bushfire takes hold too quickly and becomes very difficult to control.

"Their fall back lines aren't big enough or good enough to stop a running fire in the mountains," Mr Millear said.

"They can't burn back off anything.

"Government just needs to put money into it."

Perhaps the most striking part of the recent effort to control and eventually contain the Grampians bushfires, was the level of farmer involvement.

The Westmere group of 18 brigades benefited from the availability of as many as 400 private tankers when fighting the flames.

Mr Millear said 95pc of these private units were manned by farming men and women.

Many of these farmers gave up their Christmas to join neighbours and friends at the fire front.

"We were a very professional, well organised group," he said.

"We were really well-planned and our crews were well versed and trained.

"They did a really great job."

In total, 76,000 hectares of the national park was burned and a further 9310 hectares of private farm land.

Mr Millear said the physical and mental toll on the more than 400 volunteers was major and to put salt in their wounds, plans to hike the Fire Service Levy were coming down the track.

"All our members are a tough bunch but they're still feeling it," he said.

"Mentally, it's been a big drain."

He said the levy hike would be fought "really hard" and farmers were in talks with the opposition and the Victorian Farmers' Federation.

"That's just going to be a massive cost on volunteers," he said.

"The money won't be spent here.

"We'll fight it tooth and nail because it's far from equitable."

However, overall, Mr Millear wished to highlight the bravery and hard work of all those volunteers and farmers who stepped up to control the fires.

Westmere Fire Brigades group officer Pat Millear, Willaura, called for a common sense approach to forest fire management. Picture by Barry Murphy

urn:contentItem:6FYJ-1JW3-RRYG-K009-00000-00Mayor praises levy reprieve for farmers2025-06-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:20ZLexisNexisNEWS3Mayor praises levy reprieve for farmersBryan Hoadley

Councillors were 'united' in slamming the emergency services tax.

Ballarat's mayor says the city is pleased to hear the state government will cap its Emergency Services and Volunteer Fund (ESVF) levy for all primary production properties across Victoria, after councillors labelled the tax increase "cruel", "toxic" and "out of touch".

At a council meeting on May 28, the council unanimously passed a motion condemning the new tax as a "significant financial burden" on Victorian property owners.

The motion also called on the city to advocate for the responsibility for the collection of the ESVF to be transferred to the Victorian Treasury and for the council to write to relevant state ministers and local MPs denouncing the new tax.

Mayor Tracey Hargreaves said she was concerned by the "significant financial burden" it would place on residents, but the council was unable to refuse to collect the tax.

While deputy mayor Ben Taylor said the municipality's emergency services levy total sat at $10 million in 2020, and it would rise to $22 million under the new ESVF.

It comes after The Courier revealed that Ballarat ratepayers would see an average increase in emergency services-related payments of 45.9 per cent.

This includes a 34 per cent increase in levy charges for residential property owners on their 2025-26 rates notices, while primary production properties are facing a 148 per cent increase.

The ESVF, which was passed by parliament in the early hours of May 16, is replacing the cheaper Fire Services Property Levy and has been met with widespread fury from rural residents and councils, who feel disproportionately affected by the new tax.

Under the ESVF, additional funds will go to services including VICSES, Triple Zero Victoria and Forest Fire Management Victoria, which were not supported by the previous levy.

Just days later, on Friday, May 30, the government announced that the levy would be capped at the 2024/25 rate for all primary production properties across the state for the coming financial year.

"We understand that the rate for primary production properties will remain at 28.7, the same as it was in 2024/25 for the duration of the 2025/26 financial year," Cr Hargreaves said, following the announcement.

"This is hard-fought recognition of the unique difficulties farmers are currently facing in devastating drought conditions.

"Despite this welcome reprieve for farmers, council remains committed to the motion that was passed on Wednesday night in which all nine councillors voted to formally oppose the Emergency Services and Volunteers Fund and the mandated requirement to collect it on behalf of the state government."

On Wednesday night, the first to speak in favour of the motion was councillor Ted Lapkin, who called the ESVF a "crushing burden" for Victorian farmers.

In an impassioned speech, Cr Lapkin quoted protester placards, The Financial Review and an 1819 US Supreme Court decision, and compared the City of Ballarat to ancient Roman tax collectors.

He also called on the community to pressure their local MPs over the "outrageous tax".

"To this Labor government, country Victoria is expendable and exploitable, it sees rural regions as a source of low-hanging revenue fruit that can be taxed to the hilt," he said.

"The Victorian government's emergency services tax will destroy livelihoods and perhaps even lives ... we must express our dissent in the strongest possible terms.

"Only if ordinary Victorians exert sustained political pressure do we stand any chance at all of repealing and reversing this toxic tax."

Cr Lapkin's motion was then seconded by councillor Jay Morrison, who was also critical of the burden the ESVF would put on the city's ratepayers.

"The timing of this levy could not be worse; we are in the midst of a cost-of-living crisis," he said.

"We are not just making a statement, we are taking action, we are standing up for our community and are calling for a better, fairer approach."

When voicing his support for the motion, Cr Taylor said it would send a "clear message" that the tax was unacceptable, particularly for businesses and farmers who would experience the steepest rises.

Councillor Des Hudson recommended that future rates notices should highlight how much money would go to the ESVF, and also include contact information for state MPs so ratepayers could voice their concerns regarding the tax.

"This is unfair, it's a burden, it's at a time when we can least afford it, and we deserve a better outcome," he said.

Councillor Samantha McIntosh and councillor Damon Saunders both cited concerns for farmers' mental health while outlining their support for the motion.

"This cruel impost is going to create mental health problems," Cr Saunders said.

"This cruel and sneaky tax is abhorrent."

In also opposing the ESVF, councillor Jim Rinaldi said members of the state government "wouldn't have any idea what it's like to struggle for a dollar" and that they were "out of touch" with the ordinary person.

Finally, councillor Tess Morgan said she was "proud to hear a united voice among councillors" and urged the council to keep its share of the rates low when it came to its forthcoming budget.

"I'm proud this appears to be a [council] group aware of the cost of living," she said.

On Tuesday, neighbouring council Hepburn Shire passed a similar motion, which voiced strong opposition to the ESVF.

In a press release, the Hepburn Shire stated it would "join the many other councils opposing the levy".

City of Ballarat councillors criticised the state government's ESVF legislation at a May 28 council meeting. File picture

Weyerhaeuser (NYSE:WY $25.84), the NYSE's 5th largest Building materials & fixtures company by market cap, extended its gains in the past week ended Friday, rising an additional 36.0c (or 1.4%) to close at $25.84. The shares have climbed 76.0c (or 3.0%) over the past two weeks. Compared with the S&P 500 Index which rose 211.8 points (or 3.4%) in the two weeks, this represented a relative price change of -0.4%.

The company today announced a quarterly dividend of 21.0c per share for Q2/2025; unchanged from the previous quarter (Q1/2025) dividend of 21.0c. 1.3 January 31 2022: Weyerhaeuser reports fourth quarter, record full year results

Weyerhaeuser Company (NYSE: WY) today reported fourth quarter net earnings of $416 million, or 55 cents per diluted share, on net sales of $2.2 billion. This compares with net earnings of $292 million, or 39 cents per diluted share, on net sales of $2.1 billion for the same period last year and net earnings of $482 million for the third quarter of 2021. Excluding a total after-tax benefit of $49 million for special items, the company reported fourth quarter net earnings of $367 million, or 49 cents per diluted share. This compares with net earnings before special items of $361 million for the same period last year and $450 million for the third quarter of 2021. Adjusted EBITDA for the fourth quarter of 2021 was $674 million compared with $657 million for the same period last year and $746 million for the third quarter of 2021.

For the full year 2021, Weyerhaeuser reported record net earnings of $2.6 billion, or $3.47 per diluted share, on net sales of $10.2 billion. This compares with net earnings of $797 million on net sales of $7.5 billion for the full year 2020. Full year 2021 includes a total after-tax benefit of $81 million for special items. Excluding these items, the company reported net earnings of $2.5 billion, or $3.37 per diluted share. This compares with net earnings before special items of $962 million for the full year 2020. Adjusted EBITDA for full year 2021 was a record $4.1 billion compared with $2.2 billion for full year 2020.

This morning, the company declared a $1.45 per share supplemental dividend. On a combined basis, including dividends and share repurchase, the company is returning more than $2 billion of cash, or 79 percent of 2021 Adjusted FAD, to shareholders based on our 2021 results.

"Our 2021 financial performance was the strongest on record and each of our businesses delivered exceptional results despite persistent operational and market challenges," said Devin W.

May 28: Weyerhaeuser, Firefighter Behavioral Health Alliance Partner for Fourth Year to Provide Mental Health Resources for Wildland Firefighters

Fighting Fires Together campaign raises awareness and helps address mental health challenges of wildland firefighting

SEATTLE, May 28, 2025- Weyerhaeuser Company (NYSE: WY) and Firefighter Behavioral Health Alliance (FBHA) today announced an extension of their Fighting Fires Together campaign, a partnership that provides specialized mental health support for wildland firefighters and their families across the Pacific Northwest.

Fighting Fires Together, now in its fourth year, addresses the often-overlooked mental health impacts of wildland firefighting in isolated, hazardous and highly stressful conditions. Through a free online resource hub, first responders can find specially designed content, including videos about Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD), depression, anxiety and suicide prevention, along with mental health tips, educational articles and contacts for occupationally aware support groups and counselors in Oregon, Washington and British Columbia.

Weyerhaeuser's support for wildland firefighting efforts in the Pacific Northwest began in the aftermath of the Yacolt Burn in 1902, when the company began advocating for Washington's first forest fire legislation and the funding of community fire prevention education and patrols. Today, as Weyerhaeuser celebrates its 125th anniversary, the company continues to play an active role in fire prevention and response through its forest management operations. Weyerhaeuser employees and contractors receive annual fire readiness training, build fire breaks and containment lines, conduct aerial surveys and deploy tanker trucks, helicopters and quick-response crews to wildland fires.

"After launching the Fighting Fires Together campaign with FBHA four years ago, we're proud to continue this effort to support wildland firefighters and their mental health as they work in challenging conditions to protect our communities," says Bill Frings, vice president of Western Timberlands for Weyerhaeuser.

May 22: Weyerhaeuser Acquiring High-Quality Timberlands in North Carolina and Virginia

Capitalizing on unique off-market opportunity to further enhance Southern Timberlands portfolio with highly productive and strategically located acreage

SEATTLE, May 22, 2025 - Weyerhaeuser Company (NYSE: WY) today announced an agreement to acquire approximately 117,000 acres of high-quality timberlands in North Carolina and Virginia from Roanoke Timberlands LLC, a subsidiary of Roseburg Forest Products, for $375 million. Comprised of mature, highly productive timberlands, the acreage will be well-integrated with existing Weyerhaeuser timberland and mill operations in North Carolina, will expand the company's footprint into attractive markets in southeastern Virginia and will offer substantial alternative value opportunities. The acquisition is expected to deliver immediate and sustained portfolio-leading cash flows within the company's Southern Timberlands business.

Key attributes of the acquisition:

Located in strong and growing sawlog and fiber markets in the U.S. South Primarily fee ownership with 81 percent planted pine acreage, strong site productivity and favorable all-weather logging operability Mature planted pine age class expected to produce an average annual harvest of 7.4 tons per acre (or 860,000 tons) over the first five years Expected to deliver an average annual timber free cash flow yield of 5.1 percent over the first five years Significant optionality to capture additional upside from real estate, natural climate solutions and natural resource opportunities "These are exceptional timberlands, and we're excited and well-positioned to capitalize on this unique off-market opportunity," said Devin W. Stockfish, president and chief executive officer. "As we've demonstrated over the last several years, we are committed to active portfolio management across our unmatched timber holdings and have remained disciplined in our approach to growing the value of our timberlands - including through strategically targeted private transactions like the one we're announcing today.

May 21: Weyerhaeuser to Sell Princeton, B.C., Lumber Mill to Gorman Group

Agreement with local buyer includes manufacturing facility and associated timber licenses in British Columbia

SEATTLE, May 21, 2025 - Weyerhaeuser Company (NYSE: WY) today announced it has reached an agreement to sell its lumber mill in Princeton, British Columbia, to the Gorman Group, owners of Gorman Bros.Lumber Ltd., a family-owned wood products manufacturer headquartered in West Kelowna, B.C. The purchase price is approximately $120 million CAD in cash, which includes Weyerhaeuser's manufacturing facility, all associated timber license assets in British Columbia and the value of working capital, which will be subject to customary purchase price adjustments at closing.

Weyerhaeuser and Gorman Group have a long-standing relationship in Canada. Gorman Bros.Lumber is currently the Princeton mill's largest customer, and Gorman Group has operated in Canada for more than 75 years, with offices and facilities in B.C. and Washington state.

"We are grateful to all the dedicated employees who contributed to the success of our Princeton operations over the years," says Devin W. Stockfish, president and chief executive officer for Weyerhaeuser. "The community has always been incredibly welcoming and supportive of our mill and people, and it was important for us to sell to a local buyer with deep roots in the region. Gorman has been a great customer and strategic partner, and we believe this will be a seamless transition that will position the mill for future success in a challenging operating environment - providing long-term certainty for the mill and the broader community."

"Weyerhaeuser's Princeton operation will be a natural fit with the Gorman Group," says Nick Arkle, chief executive officer of the Gorman Group. "We've had a strong connection to the Princeton operation for many years, and we know firsthand the skill, commitment and quality that define its team.

ECONOMIC AND MARKET CONDITIONS AFFECTING OUR OPERATIONS

Our market conditions and the strength of the broader U.S. economy are, and will continue to be, influenced by the trajectory of activity in the U.S. housing and repair and remodel segments, inflation trends and interest rates. The demand for sawlogs within our Timberlands segment is directly affected by domestic production of wood-based building products. The strength of the U.S. housing market, particularly new residential construction, strongly affects demand in our Wood Products segment, as does repair and remodeling activity. Seasonal weather patterns impact the level of construction activity in the U.S., which in turn affects demand for our logs and wood products. Our Timberlands segment, specifically the Western region, is also affected by export demand and trade policy. Japanese housing starts are a key driver of export log demand in Japan. The demand for pulpwood from our Timberlands segment is directly affected by the production of pulp, paper and oriented strand board (OSB), as well as the demand for biofuels, such as wood-burning pellets made from pulpwood. Our Timberlands segment is also influenced by the availability of harvestable timber. In general, Western log markets are highly tensioned by available supply, while Southern log markets have more available supply. However, additional mill capacity being added in the U.S.

SECTION 8 CORPORATE PROFILE AND INDEPENDENT RATINGS

8.1 Activities

Weyerhaeuser Company, headquartered in Seattle, Washington, is one of the largest private owners of timberlands in the world, with a history dating back to 1900. Its core business activities center on sustainable forest management, timber harvesting, and the production of wood products. The company''s largest sources of revenue come from its Timberlands segment, which includes the sale of logs and timber, and its Wood Products segment, which manufactures and distributes lumber, engineered wood, and other building materials primarily for residential and commercial construction. Additionally, Weyerhaeuser operates a Real Estate, Energy, and Natural Resources segment, focusing on land sales and renewable energy opportunities. Among its business lines, the Wood Products segment has shown notable growth, driven by strong demand in the housing and construction markets. With a commitment to environmental stewardship, Weyerhaeuser continues to balance profitability with sustainable practices across its extensive land holdings. It is the NYSE's 5th largest Building materials & fixtures company by market capitalisation.

In FY 2024, the top earner of Revenue was WOOD PRODUCTS [68%] followed by TIMBERLANDS [26.9%] at Rank 2 and REAL ESTATE & ENR [5.1%] at Rank 3. In FY 2024, revenue growth was highest in REAL ESTATE & ENR [7.7%] .

urn:contentItem:6FJN-91G3-RTDB-T24C-00000-00Warmest April day in the city since 20142025-04-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:20ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 16Warmest April day in the city since 2014Roy Ward

Melbourne experienced its hottest April day since 2014 yesterday, with the mercury hitting 31.8 degrees in the city and weather stations at Avalon and Point Cook recording maximum temperatures of 33.5.

Bureau of Meteorology senior meteorologist Simon Timcke said Melbourne hadn't experienced an April day this hot since April 1, 2014, and experiencing a day so warm this late in April was rare.

"It's the hottest day we have had for a while," Timcke said.

"We've got to 31.8 degrees and that's our hottest April day since April 1, 2014, so 11 years since we've seen a day as hot as this in April and that day was the first of the month. To find a day this hot so late in April takes a bit of effort, and we have to go further back in the records.

"We got to 33.8 degrees on April 13, 1985, and we got to 34.4 degrees on April 17 back in 1922. It's not impossible to get days this hot late in April, but it's not very often."

The temperature will drop today to an expected top of 23 degrees with the possibility of a few showers in the morning.

But Timcke said the weather was forecast to warm up again later in the week as Easter began.

"We get another high that moves in over the Tasman Sea so the winds go northerly again, and we get a few warmer days towards the end of the week," he said.

"It looks like 26 degrees for Tuesday, 29 degrees for Wednesday and Thursday, and then 28 for Friday. So we've got a few warmer days to finish off the week."

Timcke said the warm weekend had been the result of a hot air mass in the north of Victoria.

"That's directed more northerly winds over us and dragged some of that hot air down from the north because we've had a pretty good run of pretty hot days over the north of the state for a while now," Timcke said.

"So the northerly has just brought some of that hot air down from the north."

Firefighters battled a bushfire four kilometres south-west of Daylesford yesterday afternoon.

Forest Fire Management Victoria said 72 vehicles and 250 firefighters were fighting the fire that had burnt through more than 96 hectares of land..

A watch-and-act warning was in place yesterday for the communities of Musk Vale, Sailors Falls and Sailors Hill.

urn:contentItem:6FP3-21K3-RTTG-S06G-00000-00CFA firefighters warn of risks of burning off despite restrictions lifting2025-04-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:20ZLexisNexisCFA firefighters warn of risks of burning off despite restrictions liftingSophie Else

'It's all about remaining vigilant ... don't be complacent.'

With the end of the fire danger period and the easing of fire restrictions, Border residents are being urged to take extra care when burning off.

The Country Fire Authority warns the risk of burn-offs escaping remains high in the coming weeks.

Although fire restrictions are being lifted in Wodonga, Indigo and Alpine municipalities on Thursday, May 1, District 24 assistant chief fire officer Brett Myers said now was not the time to be complacent.

He said the current level of dryness, lack of rainfall and wind could create the potential for fires to spread quite rapidly, especially in grasslands.

The CFA expected the grassfire risk to remain across Victoria and asked people to remain alert and prepared.

"The last six to eight weeks CFA, along with local government and forest fire management, have been meeting to ascertain when is the right timing to remove the fire danger restrictions," Mr Myers said.

Towong Shire restrictions still in place

"Prevailing dryness and a lack of rainfall in Towong Shire has led to an elevated risk right across that geographical area.

"The fire danger period and fire restrictions will remain in place until May 26 for all locations in Towong.

"Unless we receive substantial rain between now and then, that time frame may even push out further.

He said April and May 2024 proved the "busiest months of the year" for the CFA brigades.

"Predominantly because people were lighting up their burn-off piles on their property and not understanding the risk of that fire spreading quite quickly with minimal wind," he said.

Don't walk away from a burning fire

Landowners could take precautions to further reduce the risk when carrying out a burn on their property.

These included checking the council's regulations about when and where burning off is permitted, monitoring the weather conditions, ensuring an adequate water supply, cleaning up the perimeter of the burn site beforehand, registering the burn-off, notifying neighbours, and making sure the fire is fully extinguished afterwards.

Mr Myers said it was important to do a mineral earth line around the burn-off, which would prevent the fire from spreading further by removing the fuel.

"It is quite complacent for people to light a fire and then walk away and leave it. Before you know it, it's spread into areas that weren't intended to be burnt and potentially causing devastation," he said.

"It's all about remaining vigilant. Controlling a fire on your property is your responsibility. Make sure you understand the risk in your area and don't be complacent"

"It could be quite an embarrassing phone call to triple zero to request assistance for an out of control fire that you have inadvertently created"

More information regarding how to conduct a burnoff safely can be accessed at: www.cfa.vic.gov.au/firedangerperiod or www.firepermits.vic.gov.au .

CFA District 24 assistant chief fire officer Brett Myers says people need to be more vigilant when it comes to burning off, especially with fire restrictions lifting on Thursday, May 1. Pictures by Phoebe Adams

2.3 January 31 2022: Weyerhaeuser reports fourth quarter, record full year results

Weyerhaeuser Company (NYSE: WY) today reported fourth quarter net earnings of $416 million, or 55 cents per diluted share, on net sales of $2.2 billion. This compares with net earnings of $292 million, or 39 cents per diluted share, on net sales of $2.1 billion for the same period last year and net earnings of $482 million for the third quarter of 2021. Excluding a total after-tax benefit of $49 million for special items, the company reported fourth quarter net earnings of $367 million, or 49 cents per diluted share. This compares with net earnings before special items of $361 million for the same period last year and $450 million for the third quarter of 2021. Adjusted EBITDA for the fourth quarter of 2021 was $674 million compared with $657 million for the same period last year and $746 million for the third quarter of 2021.

For the full year 2021, Weyerhaeuser reported record net earnings of $2.6 billion, or $3.47 per diluted share, on net sales of $10.2 billion. This compares with net earnings of $797 million on net sales of $7.5 billion for the full year 2020. Full year 2021 includes a total after-tax benefit of $81 million for special items. Excluding these items, the company reported net earnings of $2.5 billion, or $3.37 per diluted share. This compares with net earnings before special items of $962 million for the full year 2020. Adjusted EBITDA for full year 2021 was a record $4.1 billion compared with $2.2 billion for full year 2020.

This morning, the company declared a $1.45 per share supplemental dividend. On a combined basis, including dividends and share repurchase, the company is returning more than $2 billion of cash, or 79 percent of 2021 Adjusted FAD, to shareholders based on our 2021 results.

"Our 2021 financial performance was the strongest on record and each of our businesses delivered exceptional results despite persistent operational and market challenges," said Devin W.

June 30: Weyerhaeuser: File SEC Form 10-Q - Management's Discussion and Analysis 10-Q

MANAGEMENT'S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS (MD&A)

NOTE ABOUT FORWARD-LOOKING STATEMENTS

This report contains statements concerning our future results and performance that are forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These include, without limitation, statements relating to: our expected future financial and operating performance; our plans, strategies, intentions and expectations; our capital structure and the sufficiency of our liquidity position to meet future cash requirements; our cash dividend framework, including our target percentage return to shareholders of Adjusted Funds Available for Distribution, including expected supplemental cash dividends and/or future share repurchases; future compliance with covenants in our debt agreements; our expectations concerning our contingent liabilities and the sufficiency of related reserves and accruals including, but not limited to, cost estimates of future litigation and environmental remediation; our provision for income taxes; expected capital expenditures; estimated returns on pension plan assets; expected market and general economic conditions, including related influencing factors such as the trajectory of U.S. housing construction activity, repair and remodel activity, inflation trends and interest rates and the potential impacts of U.S. trade policy; our expectations about our future opportunities in emerging carbon credit and carbon capture and storage markets; assumptions used in valuing incentive compensation and related expense; the expected effects of U.S. international trade policy and the occurrence and timing of the closing of an announced timberland acquisition transaction and the occurrence and timing of the closing of an announced wood products manufacturing facility sale transaction.

Forward-looking statements can be identified by the fact that they do not relate strictly to historical or current facts.

June 26: Weyerhaeuser to Release Second Quarter Results on July 24

Webcast and conference call on July 25 at 7 a.m. PT (10 a.m. ET)

SEATTLE, June 26, 2025 - Weyerhaeuser Company (NYSE: WY) will release second quarter 2025 results on Thursday, July 24, after the market closes. The company will then hold a live webcast and conference call the following day, on Friday, July 25, at 7 a.m. Pacific (10 a.m. Eastern), to discuss the results.

To access the earnings release, live webcast and presentation online, visit the Investor Relations section on www.weyerhaeuser.com.

To join the conference call from within North America, dial 877-407-0792 (access code: 13748397) at least 15 minutes prior to the call. Those calling from outside North America should dial 201-689-8263 (access code: 13748397). Replays will be available for two weeks at 844-512-2921 (access code: 13748397) from within North America, and at 412-317-6671 (access code: 13748397) from outside North America.

Press Release article 3 of 3, Source: Company Website, 284 words

May 28: Weyerhaeuser, Firefighter Behavioral Health Alliance Partner for Fourth Year to Provide Mental Health Resources for Wildland Firefighters

Fighting Fires Together campaign raises awareness and helps address mental health challenges of wildland firefighting

SEATTLE, May 28, 2025- Weyerhaeuser Company (NYSE: WY) and Firefighter Behavioral Health Alliance (FBHA) today announced an extension of their Fighting Fires Together campaign, a partnership that provides specialized mental health support for wildland firefighters and their families across the Pacific Northwest.

Fighting Fires Together, now in its fourth year, addresses the often-overlooked mental health impacts of wildland firefighting in isolated, hazardous and highly stressful conditions. Through a free online resource hub, first responders can find specially designed content, including videos about Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD), depression, anxiety and suicide prevention, along with mental health tips, educational articles and contacts for occupationally aware support groups and counselors in Oregon, Washington and British Columbia.

Weyerhaeuser's support for wildland firefighting efforts in the Pacific Northwest began in the aftermath of the Yacolt Burn in 1902, when the company began advocating for Washington's first forest fire legislation and the funding of community fire prevention education and patrols. Today, as Weyerhaeuser celebrates its 125th anniversary, the company continues to play an active role in fire prevention and response through its forest management operations. Weyerhaeuser employees and contractors receive annual fire readiness training, build fire breaks and containment lines, conduct aerial surveys and deploy tanker trucks, helicopters and quick-response crews to wildland fires.

"After launching the Fighting Fires Together campaign with FBHA four years ago, we're proud to continue this effort to support wildland firefighters and their mental health as they work in challenging conditions to protect our communities," says Bill Frings, vice president of Western Timberlands for Weyerhaeuser.

SECTION 5 10-Q: 12 CONSEQUENTIAL MANAGEMENT DECISIONS

<p><strong>Strategic Expansion of Engineered Wood Products Capacity</strong></p>

<p>Management has committed $500 million to constructing a new TimberStrand facility in Monticello, Arkansas, beginning in 2025, with operations expected by 2027. This investment is projected to expand engineered wood products capacity by 10 million cubic feet, positioning Weyerhaeuser to seize greater market share in the growing housing sector. While the long-term growth and revenue potential align with favorable housing trends, the funding approach-whether via existing cash or external financing-could pressure short-term liquidity or increase debt levels.</p>

<p><strong>Shareholder Value Enhancement Through New $1 Billion Buyback Program</strong></p>

<p>Following completion of a prior program, management authorized a new $1 billion share repurchase initiative in May 2025. This move underscores confidence in company valuation and enhances earnings per share by reducing outstanding shares. While the initiative aligns with the shareholder return framework targeting 75-80% of Adjusted FAD, it reflects a strategic trade-off by potentially limiting capital allocation flexibility during potential market volatility.</p>

<p><strong>Maintaining Dividend Stability Amid Economic Challenges</strong></p>

<p>Weyerhaeuser continues its cash dividend framework, targeting a 75-80% payout of Adjusted FAD, and has paid $304 million in 2025 dividends thus far. The year-to-date payout decline-due primarily to an absence of supplemental dividends in Q1-highlights the company's adaptability to fluctuating cash flows. For income-focused investors, this consistent dividend policy provides predictability, though variability in Adjusted FAD may influence future distributions.</p>

<p><strong>Strengthened Liquidity with an Updated Credit Facility</strong></p>

<p>The company amended and restated its revolving credit facility in June 2025, increasing capacity to $1.75 billion and extending maturity to 2030. This ensures access to substantial liquidity without current borrowings, providing operational flexibility while reducing refinancing risks during economic uncertainty. The alignment of covenant compliance further supports Weyerhaeuser's credit profile.</p>

<p><strong>Capital Optimization through Debt Repayment and Refinancing</strong></p>

<p>Management refinanced maturing debt by repaying $210 million in debentures while issuing a $300 million senior unsecured term loan maturing in 2030. This strategic action reduced the weighted average interest rate, trimming interest expense by $2 million year-to-date, while preserving $592 million in cash and full credit availability. For investors, this showcases disciplined capital allocation, though possible fluctuations in interest rates remain a key consideration.</p>

<p><strong>Focused Capital Investments to Drive Operational Efficiency</strong></p>

<p>Excluding the Monticello project, management outlined $400 million in planned 2025 capital expenditures, with $200 million deployed so far. This includes both Timberland and Wood Products maintenance expansions designed to sustain production efficiency. Despite a year-over-year increase, such investments affirm a long-term strategy to sharpen competitiveness-though revenue pressure could strain cash flow in adverse market conditions.</p>

<p><strong>Expansion into Carbon Markets to Capture Sustainability Growth</strong></p>

<p>Weyerhaeuser progresses in leveraging its natural climate solutions, capitalizing on the growing demand for carbon credits and renewable energy. By positioning itself within key sustainability sectors, management aims to unlock new revenue streams while aligning with global decarbonization goals. Though regulatory adjustments and market development require monitoring, this initiative offers potential upside for forward-looking investors.</p>

<p><strong>Unlocking Value Through Strategic Divestitures</strong></p>

<p>The announced sale of a wood products manufacturing facility (pending regulatory approvals) reflects Weyerhaeuser's strategy to streamline operations and optimize its asset base. If successful, this move could free up cash for reinvestment in higher-margin opportunities and improve overall profitability. However, pending closures introduce timing uncertainties for short-term financial performance.</p>

<p><strong>Timberland Acquisition to Strengthen Strategic Resource Base</strong></p>

<p>Management advanced a timberland acquisition that remains subject to regulatory approval. This investment supports long-term timber supply needs for the Timberlands segment while positioning the company in tightening log markets. The targeted synergies enhance revenue potential, though integration risks and upfront costs require careful oversight.</p>

<p><strong>Operational Efficiency Improvements Amid Inflationary Pressures</strong></p>

<p>Initiatives to restructure manufacturing processes and reduce costs address inflation-driven challenges related to raw materials, energy, and labor. By improving cost structures, Weyerhaeuser aims to mitigate margin compression and enhance profitability. Successful implementation will be key, especially given labor market constraints influencing production continuity.</p>

<p><strong>Proactive Risk Management for Contingent Liabilities</strong></p>

<p>Reserves for litigation and environmental responsibilities demonstrate management's financial diligence in safeguarding against operational uncertainties. By maintaining adequate coverage for contingent liabilities, Weyerhaeuser bolsters its balance sheet resilience. However, potential over-reserving may tie up capital unnecessarily and requires vigilant management assessment.</p>

<p><strong>Prioritizing Workforce Stability Amid Labor Market Tightness</strong></p>

<p>Recognizing a 4.1% unemployment rate as a constraint, Weyerhaeuser focused on hiring and talent retention across its segments. Stability in workforce availability ensures operational continuity and supports management's strategic initiatives. However, rising labor costs remain a potential margin-pressure risk-a critical area to monitor for sustained profitability.</p>

SECTION 10 CORPORATE PROFILE AND INDEPENDENT RATINGS

10.1 Activities

Weyerhaeuser Company, headquartered in Seattle, Washington, is one of the largest private owners of timberlands in the world, with a history dating back to 1900. Its core business activities center on sustainable forest management, timber harvesting, and the production of wood products. The company''s largest sources of revenue come from its Timberlands segment, which includes the sale of logs and timber, and its Wood Products segment, which manufactures and distributes lumber, engineered wood, and other building materials primarily for residential and commercial construction. Additionally, Weyerhaeuser operates a Real Estate, Energy, and Natural Resources segment, focusing on land sales and renewable energy opportunities. Among its business lines, the Wood Products segment has shown notable growth, driven by strong demand in the housing and construction markets. With a commitment to environmental stewardship, Weyerhaeuser continues to balance profitability with sustainable practices across its extensive land holdings. It is the NYSE's 5th largest Building materials & fixtures company by market capitalisation.

In FY 2024, the top earner of Revenue was WOOD PRODUCTS [68%] followed by TIMBERLANDS [26.9%] at Rank 2 and REAL ESTATE & ENR [5.1%] at Rank 3. In FY 2024, revenue growth was highest in REAL ESTATE & ENR [7.7%].

11.2 Profiles of Top Management

Devin W. Stockfish

CEO & President & Director

Devin W. Stockfish has been President and Chief Executive Officer since Jan. 1, 2019. He also serves on the company's board of directors. Previously, he served as the company's Senior Vice President, Timberlands; Senior Vice President, General Counsel and Corporate Secretary; and as Vice President, Western Timberlands. Before joining Weyerhaeuser, he was Vice President & Associate General Counsel at Univar Inc., where he focused on mergers and acquisitions, corporate governance and securities law. Previously, he was an attorney in the law department at Starbucks Corporation and practiced corporate law at K&L Gates LLP. Before he began practicing law, he was an engineer with the Boeing Company. He received his J.D. from Columbia University School of Law and holds a Bachelor of Science degree in mechanical engineering from the University of Colorado.

Rick R. Holley

Independent Chairman

Qualifications:

Mr. Holley, one of the longest tenured chief executive officers in the timber industry, has a deep and broad understanding of the company's industry and business lines, as well as experience in strategic planning and finance.

David M. Wold

CFO & Senior Vice President

David M. "Davie" Wold has been Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer since May 13, 2022. Previously, Wold served as Vice President and Chief Accounting Officer, and since joining Weyerhaeuser in November 2013 he has held a series of accounting and finance leadership roles, including serving as Corporate Controller from March 2018 to May 2019. Prior to joining the company, Wold served as Vice President, Finance, for Verdiem Corporation, a privately held technology company, from September 2011 to November 2013, and he previously spent nine years with the accounting firm of KPMG. Wold earned a Bachelor of Arts in business and finance and a Bachelor of Science in accounting from George Fox University, and he is a certified public accountant in the state of Washington.

Denise M. Merle

Chief Administrative Officer & Senior Vice President

Denise M. Merle has been Senior Vice President and Chief Administration Officer, since February 2018. She oversees Human Resources, Information Technology, Communications, Government Affairs, Environmental Affairs and Safety. Prior to her current role, she was Senior Vice President of HR and IT from 2016 to 2018 and Senior Vice President, HR and Investor Relations from 2014 to 2016. She was Director, Finance and Human Resources for the Lumber business from 2013 to 2014, Director, Compliance & Enterprise Planning from 2009 to 2013, and Director of Internal Audit from 2004 to 2009. She also held various roles in the company's former paper and packaging businesses, including finance, capital planning and analysis, and business development. She joined the company in 1981. She is a licensed CPA in the state of Washington. She holds a Bachelor of Accounting degree from Pacific Lutheran University and an MBA from Seattle University. She serves on the Board of Advisors of the Seattle University business school.

Russell S. Hagen

Senior Vice President & Chief Development Officer

Russell S. Hagen has been Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer since February 19, 2016. Previously, he was Senior Vice President, Business Development at Plum Creek, overseeing the company's business development activities, including acquisitions and dispositions, while continuing to manage the energy and natural resource business. Hagen began his career in 1988 with PricewaterhouseCoopers LLC where he was a certified public accountant and led the audits of public clients in the technology, banking and natural resource industries. He joined Plum Creek in 1993 as Manager of Internal Audit and held director-level positions in accounting, financial operations, risk management and information technology. Prior to his last role, he was Vice President, Real Estate Development, overseeing the development activities of the company's real estate, oil and gas, construction materials and bioenergy businesses. He received a Bachelor of Science in business and accounting from Seattle University. He serves on the Board of Advisors of the Seattle University business school where he has also been an adjunct lecturer.
