Director

Al Monaco, a director of the Company since February 2020, has served as president and chief executive officer and a director of Enbridge Inc., one of the largest energy infrastructure companies in North America, since 2012. Mr. Monaco is a director of the American Petroleum Institute and serves on its executive and finance committees. He is also a member of the U.S. National Petroleum Council, the Business Council of Canada, the Business Council of Alberta, and the Catalyst Canada Advisory Board. Mr. Monaco has extensive experience leading a large, complex and geographically diverse organization, as well as managing capital-intensive businesses, development of natural resources, technology, international operations, strategic planning and public company executive compensation. He also holds the chartered professional accountant and certified management accountant designations.

O'Rourke James Calvin

Director

James "Joc" C. O'Rourke, appointed as a director of the Company in 2023, has served as president and chief executive officer and a director of The Mosaic Company (mining) since 2015. In previous roles with Mosaic, he was executive vice president - operations and chief operating officer from 2012 to 2015, and executive vice president - operations from 2009 to 2012. Prior to Mosaic, Mr. O'Rourke was president of Australia Pacific for Barrick Gold Corporation, the largest gold producer in Australia, and he has held various management, engineering and other roles in the mining industry in Canada and Australia. He also serves as a director, chair of the Compensation and Human Resources Committee and member of the Nominating and Governance Committee of The Toro Company. Mr. O'Rourke has more than 25 years of experience in mining and processing and commodities markets, including managing international supply chains, procurement and customers, as well as deep leadership expertise in driving innovation, operational efficiency, safety and sustainability performance.

Lawrence A. Selzer

Independent Director

Lawrence A. Selzer has served as the president and chief executive officer of The Conservation Fund (one of the nation's premiere environmental non-profit organizations) since 2001. He is the chairman of the board of directors of American Bird Conservancy and a member of the board of trustees of Manomet. He previously served on the board of directors of Plum Creek (timber) until February 2016 and as chairman of the board of directors of Outdoor Foundation from 2007 until 2016.

Qualifications:

Mr. Selzer has experience and expertise in the areas of conservation procurement, conservation finance, land acquisition and disposition, and real estate management. He has experience managing and overseeing a large, complex, and geographically diverse environmental conservation organization.

Nicole W. Piasecki

Independent Director

Nicole W. Piasecki served as vice president and general manager of the Propulsion Systems Division of Boeing Commercial Airplanes from March 2013 to September 2017. Previously, she served as vice president of Business Development & Strategic Integration for Boeing Commercial Airplanes from 2010 to March 2013; president of Boeing Japan from 2006 to 2010; vice president of Business Strategy & Marketing for Boeing Commercial Airplanes from 2003 to 2006; vice president of Sales, Leasing Companies, for Boeing Commercial Airplanes from 2000 until January 2003; and served in various positions in engineering, sales, marketing, and business strategy for the Commercial Aircraft Group since 1992. She is the vice chair of the board of trustees of Seattle University in Seattle, Washington, a former director on the Seattle Branch board of directors for the Federal Reserve Bank, and a former member of the board of governors, Tokyo, of the American Chamber of Commerce of Japan, and the Federal Aviation's Administration Advisory Council.

Qualifications:

Ms. Piasecki has extensive executive experience in capital-intensive industries, sales and marketing, strategic planning and international operations and relations.

Deidra C. Merriwether

Independent Director

Dee Merriwether, appointed as a director of the Company in 2020, has served as senior vice president and chief financial officer for W.W. Grainger, Inc. (industrial maintenance, repair and operating products supply) since January 2021. In previous roles with Grainger, she was the senior vice president and president of North American Sales and Services until January 2021, senior vice president of Direct Sales and Strategic Initiatives from 2016 to 2020, and vice president of Finance, Americas, from 2013 to 2016. Prior to Grainger, she was with Sears as chief operating officer of Retail Formats from 2011 to 2013; senior vice president and chief financial officer of Retail Formats from 2008 to 2011; vice president of Procurement & Merger Integration from 2004 to 2008; and vice president of Kmart Real Estate Strategy from 2002 to 2004. She has also served in various other finance, production and management roles with Sears, Isiah Investments, PricewaterhouseCoopers and Eli Lilly & Company. Ms. Merriwether served on the board of directors of Sears Canada from 2007 to 2010. She has broad-based and deep management experience in the areas of sales, international supply chain and finance, as well as significant P&L responsibilities.

Mark A. Emmert

Independent Director

Mark A. Emmert has been the president of the National Collegiate Athletic Association since 2010. He served as president of the University of Washington in Seattle, Washington, from 2004 to 2010; as chancellor of Louisiana State University from 1999 to 2004; and chancellor and provost of the University of Connecticut from 1994 to 1999. Prior to 1994, he was provost and vice president for Academic Affairs at Montana State University and held faculty and administrative positions at the University of Colorado. He also is a director of Expeditors International of Washington, Inc. (global logistics services). He previously served on the board of directors of Omnicare, Inc. (healthcare services) until 2015.

Qualifications:

Mr. Emmert is a Life Member of the Council on Foreign Relations and is a Fellow of the National Academy of Public Administration. He has also been a Fulbright Fellow, a Fellow of the American Council on Education and served on many non-profit boards. He is an experienced leader of major organizations, with strong skills in government and international relations, strategic planning and public company executive compensation.

Sara Grootwassink Lewis

Independent Director

Sara Grootwassink Lewis founded, and is the chief executive officer of, Lewis Corporate Advisors (capital markets advisory firm). From 2002 to 2009, she was chief financial officer of Washington Real Estate Investment Trust Company (equity real estate investment trust). Ms. Grootwassink Lewis also serves on the board of directors of PS Business Parks, Inc. (commercial real estate), and Sun Life Financial Inc. (global financial services). She previously served on the board of directors of CapitalSource, Inc. (commercial lending) from 2004 until its acquisition in 2014, Plum Creek (timber) until February 2016 and Adamas Pharmaceuticals, Inc. (specialty pharmaceuticals) until June 2016.

Qualifications:

Ms. Grootwassink Lewis is a member of the board of trustees of The Brookings Institution and the leadership board of the United States Chamber of Commerce Center for Capital Markets Competitiveness, and a former member of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board Standing Advisory Group from 2015-2017. Ms. Grootwassink Lewis has extensive executive, financial and real estate industry experience, having served as a senior executive of a publicly traded REIT as well as service on several public company boards. Ms. Grootwassink Lewis also holds a chartered financial analyst designation.

Kim Williams

Independent Director

Kim Williams, a director of the Company since 2006, was senior vice president and associate director of global industry research for Wellington Management Company LLP (investment management) from 2001 to 2005, was elected a partner effective in 1995 and held various management positions with Wellington from 1986 to 2001. Prior to joining Wellington, she served as vice president, industry analyst for Loomis, Sayles & Co., Inc (investment management) from 1982 to 1985. Ms. Williams also serves as board chair for E.W. Scripps Company (diverse media) as well as chair of the audit and executive committees and serves on the board of directors of Xcel Energy Inc. (utilities). She previously served as a director for MicroVest (asset management firm) until its acquisition in 2021. Ms. Williams is a member of the Women's Health Leadership Council of Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston, Massachusetts, a member of the board of OxfamAmerica (global antipoverty agency) and a life trustee of Concord Academy. Ms. Williams has extensive experience in corporate finance, strategic planning and international operations.

urn:contentItem:6FVY-TFB3-RSTW-F2C2-00000-00Hero to whipping boy, Labor’s latest tax grab push volunteers to tears2025-05-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:20ZLexisNexisHero to whipping boy, Labor’s latest tax grab push volunteers to tears

Protesters gathered at the steps of parliament house on Thursday. Photo: Jackie Peacock

In the early hours of Friday May 16, Labor and members of the Animal Justice Party, The Greens and Legalise Cannabis Party, colluded with the Allan Labor Government to pass their latest tax, the Emergency Services and ‘Volunteers’ Fund. Those hardest hit by the tax will be country Victorians, a large portion of those CFA volunteers.

The Nationals Member for Murray Plains, Peter Walsh, has labelled the new Emergency Services Levy as a land tax by stealth – targeting the farming community in particular – and as “socialism gone mad in Victoria”.

Protesters gathered at the steps of parliament house on Thursday. Photo: Jackie Peacock

He said the new ‘levy’ is the Allan Labor government “conniving to push through an unprecedented and deliberate land tax on farms”.

“Agricultural land, which is what feeds and clothes this state, and this country, has rightly been exempt for this traditionally pernicious cash grab for obvious reasons.”

Walsh said this is now about every property in Victoria being hit with an increased land tax.

“With this tax the Premier and her bloated bureaucracy are ignoring the voices of everyday Victorians who are saying enough is enough,” Mr Walsh added.

“Labor has wasted tens of billions of dollars on cost blowouts on its ridiculous and corruption-riddled major projects in Melbourne, and now they want to have a land tax to make up that huge black hole,” he said.

“This is Labor showing its contempt for the common people and giving us a frightening glimpse of its socialist lunacy.”

Gannawarra Shire Council has joined municipalities across Victoria to oppose the State Government’s implementation of the Emergency Services and Volunteers Fund.

The fund, to come into effect from July, will replace the Fire Services Levy and will be used to support VICSES, Triple Zero Victoria, the State Control Centre, Forest Fire Management Victoria and Emergency Recovery Victoria, as well as the Country Fire Authority (CFA) and Fire Rescue Victoria (FRV).

As with the former Fire Services Levy, local government will be responsible for collecting payment as part of the annual municipal rates process, with the amount each landowner is required to pay to increase compared to the previous levy. The amount this will increase will depend on the property’s land classification.

“My fellow Councillors and I outrightly oppose this unjustifiable levy that all landowners in the Gannawarra Shire will face. We must stand up for our community against this blatant cash grab,” Mayor Garner Smith said.

“Many of our landowners have already been hit with massive increases in land tax, and this new tax is estimated to take millions of dollars away from our residents. This will have a flow-on effect on our local businesses and sectors, especially the agriculture sector.

Protesters gathered at the steps of parliament house on Thursday. Photo: Jackie Peacock

“All this levy will do is fund activities and organisations that have previously been funded out of general tax revenue. The State Government must show the people of Gannawarra how the money raised from this levy will flow back to our community.”

As part of its opposition to the implementation of the fund, Gannawarra Shire Council requests that the Municipal Association of Victoria and Rural Councils Victoria investigate ways councils can avoid collecting this funding from landowners.

“The expense and administrative burden our staff will face in determining the cost of this levy, then asking landowners to pay, will be huge,” Mayor Smith said.

“The State Government has options available for collecting this levy, including the State Revenue Office, which collects land tax on behalf of the government

“It is important that our residents know that this decision has nothing to do with Council. My fellow Councillors, Council staff and I will take every opportunity to raise our objection to this levy with the State Government on behalf of our community.”

Jackie Peacock, a digital creator from near St Arnaud Victoria, attended the rally and said morale in her community was very low.

“I’m seeing a lot of people getting more desperate and maybe not being themselves,” said Jackie.

“I think they are really feeling like they’re unheard and they don’t matter.”

“Their mental health thing is something that’s probably not being fully recognised, especially out here when we don’t have good opportunities to seek professional help.”

“It’s a real worry. I just want people to know that they matter.”

Link to Image

This article appeared in The Koondrook and Barham Bridge Newspaper, 22 May 2025.

urn:contentItem:6FY4-2Y93-SGV9-11F9-00000-00Why Ballarat faces an increased risk of bushfire over the winter months2025-06-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:20ZLexisNexisWhy Ballarat faces an increased risk of bushfire over the winter monthsMichelle Smith

Bushfire outlook predicts increased risk of bushfire over winter.

Burn-offs that spread to nearby grassland and bushfire across Ballarat in recent days have underscored the increased risk of bushfire during the winter months.

Official forecasts have placed Ballarat and much of western Victoria at an increased risk of bushfire during winter after autumn rains failed, leaving bush and grasslands dry.

The increased fire risk over the winter months comes after Ballarat received just over a third of the long-term average autumn rainfall.

CFA assistant chief fire officer Lachlan Redman said fires in the past month were an example of what could occur during winter.

A recent burnoff conducted on a calm day, spread when wind got up and burned out into grassland and private property and earlier this week on the outskirts of Clunes , 10 CFA trucks responded to a large grassfire which burned through 10 hectares.

And on Sunday, near Cape Clear, a burn-off spread to long grass and trees resulting in an emergency response from multiple brigades around the area.

"We really can not stress enough that the abnormally dry conditions still pose a great risk for things to go sideways. Please make sure you are over prepared when doing any burning off and do not be complacent. Just because summer is over and our days are colder does not mean fires are not a risk," Cape Clear CFA said in a social media post.

"We are going to continue to see above average fire behaviour, and greater intensity of fire behaviour than we normally see at this time of year," Mr Redman said.

"The bush ... and native grassland and stubble will still burn quite well."

That type of fire is exactly what the Australian and New Zealand Fire and Emergency Services Council (AFAC) Seasonal Bushfire Outlook for winter warns is likely across the region.

March and April saw the fourth-highest temperatures on record, below-average rainfall across much of Victoria and an extension of the Fire Danger Period in some parts of the state for the first time since 2019.

These conditions, coupled with existing underlying dryness, have led to a higher level of dried grass and vegetation.

The increased risk isn't for long-running bushfires, but events caused by uncontrolled burn-offs and other activities.

Just 13.8 millimetres of rain fell in Ballarat during May making it the driest month since March 2024. The average rainfall for the month of May in Ballarat is 63.9 millimetres.

Fires are possible on dry and windy days in areas with dry or cured vegetation.

While the small amount of rain has created a "green tinge" across paddocks and grassland, Mr Redman warned it was still dry.

A green drought

"We haven't had enough rain to promote growth but there will be a green tinge," he said.

"It's a green drought ... dams are dry and farmers are having to destock. If and when we do get rain we will see prolific grass growth, then they won't have the stock to graze the grass out, so longer term we might experience more fires."

Mr Redman said burnoffs and campfires would remain a particular concern, especially if windy conditions are forecast.

"Be mindful when doing burns. Look at the forecast and if it's going to windy, looking as far out (at the forecast) as you can see ... if there's a day of wind we probably advice don't go ahead with the burn off," he said.

"And the bush remains so dry. If you have a campfire in the bush, look at the conditions, the wind, and make sure you fully extinguish it when you finish."

Campfire warning

Forest Fire Management has also issued a warning around campfires, in the lead-up to the King's Birthday long weekend.

FFMV chief fire officer Chris Hardman said with cooler temperatures settling in, it might feel like the fire risk had passed but campfires could quickly escape and become devastating bushfires.

"Even at this time of year, just one unattended or poorly managed campfire can cause serious damage to the environment and put lives and property at risk," Mr Hardman said.

"This season, we've responded to more than 370 incidents involving campfires. This included the Boroka Lookout Fire, where an illegal campfire turned into a bushfire in difficult terrain, on the edge of the cliff diverting resources responding to bushfires in the Grampians National Park."

Mr Redman said the winter bushfire outlook meant there would likely be little respite for CFA crews already exhausted from a long and intense summer bushfire period.

"Unfortunately, we're not seeing any respite before the next fire season," he said.

Acting CFA chief officer Garry Cook urged people not to become complacent in winter.

"The lack of rainfall and dry vegetation across many parts of the state is a great concern for firefighters this time of the year and we're asking people to remain vigilant and not become complacent just because we're not in summer anymore," Mr Cook said.

"While cooler days are arriving, the landscape remains dry enough to allow fires to start and spread quickly if a burn-off gets out of control, especially when coupled with strong winds.

"The impact and damage of an escaped fire on local communities and emergency services can be devastating."

Winter is a time when traditionally the CFA switch to fire safety messaging around smoke alarms, checking appliances and ensuring home chimney flues are cleaned prior to using but there would still need to be a focus on bushfire and grassfires.

While normal rainfall is expected across parts of Victoria, last week Bureau of Meteorology climatologist Jonathan Pollock said Ballarat could expect average rainfall for June but there were "strong signals" of lower than average rainfall in July and August.

urn:contentItem:6FW6-BKK3-RS71-M4VC-00000-00'Premier should be feeling the pressure'2025-05-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:20ZLexisNexisSaturday6'Premier should be feeling the pressure'Jonathon Magrath

Nats leader Danny O'Brien says the premier was 'under pressure'.

How the Nationals plan to maintain momentum in Bendigo ahead of the state election

Jacinta Allan should be feeling the pressure in her home electorate, according to the leader of the Victorian Nationals.

Danny O'Brien said in the wake of the federal election, in which Bendigo had the biggest swing away from Labor with 10 per cent, the Nationals had momentum in the region.

That momentum would be aided by the controversial emergency services levy the state government passed this week, he said.

"The premier should be feeling the pressure in her home seat," Mr O'Brien said in a Bendigo press conference. "I mean, she tried to claim credit for the federal election result in Victoria, saying it was a reflection on her government, but somehow a 10 per cent swing, the biggest swing against the Labor Party federally in her own hometown, was nothing to do with her. I mean, come on, you can't have it both ways."

Mr O'Brien stood alongside Victorian upper house member Gaelle Broad criticising the Allan government's 2025/26 budget for not delivering for Bendigo.

"There are things on paper, but it's whether or not the actual government delivers on what they say because time and time again, they've said big things, they've talked the big talk, but we haven't seen that in reality," Ms Broad said.

She said the government didn't have any left over to fund Bendigo projects, such as an upgrade to intersection in Maiden Gully that could lead to thousands of homes being built.

The Nationals and Liberals in Victoria announced they would "scrap" the emergency services levy if voted in at the 2026 state election.

Mr O'Brien said regional Victorians would be hit worst by the levy, which would fund services provided by Fire Rescue Victoria and the Country Fire Authority.

The Victorian government said the Emergency Services and Volunteers Levy would expand the services funded by the existing Fire Services Property Levy to include VICSES, Triple Zero Victoria, the State Control Centre, Forest Fire Management and Emergency Recovery Victoria.

Funds raised would go towards vital life-saving equipment, vehicles, staff, training for volunteers, community education and recovery support, the state government said.

"The new emergency services tax is $3 billion of extra cost to Victoria over the next four years," Mr O'Brien said.

"In Bendigo, the additional cost here for that tax is going to be $8 million out of this city. That's a big hit, that's money not being spent in our local economies, in our local shops, it's an impact on businesses ... that's why the Liberals and Nationals have promised to scrap that tax."

The federal Nationals ran a strong campaign at the federal election, with star candidate Andrew Lethlean closing the gap to retaining MP Lisa Chesters.

Mr O'Brien hinted the Victorian Nationals would look to do something similar at the November 2026 state election.

"Certainly, post the federal election, we think there's an opportunity for us to establish a stronger presence here in Bendigo," he said. "We've already got Gaelle [Broad] based here as the upper house member, we've had that for over a number of years and we think that regional cities are looking for an opportunity to vote differently. The federal election showed that they're prepared to put their faith in the Nationals when we have a good candidate, a great, strong local champion, and we'll certainly be continuing to be here and establish that presence."

It was unclear at this time if Mr Lethlean would contest the state election.

"Andrew did an absolutely stellar job here in Bendigo and we would hope that we'll have a similar candidate for the state election when it comes up next year," Mr O'Brien said.

The Nationals have contested Ms Allan's seat of Bendigo East once in the past three years, with Ms Broad receiving 16 per cent of the primary vote in 2018.

Ms Allan won the 2022 election with 60.8 per cent of the two-party-preferred vote.

The seat of Bendigo East appears to be more of a target for the Victorian Coalition, with Bendigo West held comfortably by MP Maree Edwards since 2010.

Ms Allan said she would "continue to fight hard" for her electorate.

"As a proud Bendigo local, it's a true privilege to represent the community of Bendigo East in Parliament - and I'll continue to work hard every single day. This election offered a clear choice - and the people of Bendigo chose a government that's on their side. Lisa Chesters offered a future that says yes to Medicare, renewable energy, free TAFE, infrastructure, workers' rights, and the values of opportunity and compassion, while the Nationals ran a fly-in campaign that spent millions, paid volunteers and couldn't buy genuine local trust in Bendigo."

Member for Northern Victoria Gaelle Broad and leader of the Victorian National Party Danny O'Brien. Picture by Enzo Tomasiello

urn:contentItem:6FT6-9SC3-RYCH-B3TD-00000-00More work needed on methane2025-05-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:20ZLexisNexisLETTERSPg. 21More work needed on methane

It's no surprise World Angus Forum chair Erica Halliday believes her industry isn't "harming the planet" ("Beef industry harming the planet? Nature says otherwise," TWT, May 7).

While progress has been made, and the Hallidays' regenerative work at Ben Nevis Angus in Walcha is commendable, the industry's major issue - potent enteric methane, which accounts for 80-90 per cent of its annual emissions -remains unresolved.

The Walcha Carbon Group's efforts to improve soil carbon are a strong example of positive action. However, Meat & Livestock Australia still leans heavily on reduced land clearing since 2005 in its emissions narrative. Real emission reduction must be the aim.

But achieving that is difficult. As Professor Richard Eckard of Melbourne University noted regarding his research at Jigsaw Farms in Victoria, carbon sequestration through forestry is only a temporary fix and "unless you do something about the methane, you're not going to stay net zero." Research from Central Queensland University - using water-soluble methane-reducing additives in paddock water - is promising. The four World Angus Forum sessions in Brisbane on carbon and methane emissions could make valuable reading in this paper.

Ray Peck, Hawthorn

Compensation cry We cannot afford to lose experienced and dedicated CFA volunteers. But according to the government's website, "active volunteers and life members of the CFA" are exempt. It also says, "single farm enterprises" will receive concessions.

Most income will come from city ratepayers. But even here, pensioners and veterans will receive concessions.

Where farmers use their own time and equipment to fight fires or participate in roadside burns, this should be appropriately recognised and compensated.

Where planned burns by Forest Fire Management Victoria escape, as happened recently near Daylesford, the state government should pay compensation to those farmers who used their own equipment to fight it. The federal government should implement a "polluters pay" levy on coal and gas producers proposed by senior economists Ross Garnaut and Rod Sims.

It would raise about $100bn per annum and would help regional communities increasingly threatened by climate-fuelled fires and floods.

Sue Rechter, Talbot

Hurt hits harder Farmers across Victoria, particularly in the southwest, are facing the worst drought in decades.

Dams are drying out, and a lack of rain over the Easter break means even if it does rain now, it's unlikely any feed will grow over winter due to the cold temperatures.

There is very little fodder available in Victoria, South Australia or most of NSW.

This scarcity has a double impact on the cost of keeping stock alive, with both fodder prices and the cost to freight across increasing distances soaring.

Last month, the South Australian government boosted its drought support to $73m, including much needed fodder and water freight relief, mental health support and even significant rebates on the emergency services tax.

Meanwhile, in Victoria, instead of expanding support to our farmers like other states, the Allan Labor government has slugged Victoria's food producers with a huge new tax.

Regional communities and farmers are set to be hit hardest with tax hikes up to 189 per cent. This won't just hurt farmers, but will drive up the cost of groceries for every household.

Our food producers in Victoria deserve real support when they need it - not to be forgotten and taxed into oblivion.

Emma Kealy MP, Victorian Nationals deputy leader

Unity wins through Our members stand to lose between 30-40 per cent of their turnover because of the ban of live sheep exports. The pain has already started with the number of sheep available to transport at very low levels.

Notwithstanding the devastating impact of the looming ban, the camaraderie and solidarity between our members, rural communities and others that support us has been heartwarming Apart from raising awareness about the impact the ban will have on families, country towns and rural businesses, we brought our world to life for many in the city who, until the Keep the Sheep campaign, were not aware of all the interconnected parts of the livestock supply chain One of our priorities now is to support our members through what is a very challenging time In true country style, we will look out for one another, and I urge everyone to keep an eye on their neighbours Ben Sutherland, WA Livestock and Rural Transport Association president

urn:contentItem:6F8K-CNT3-RRVY-X1B4-00000-00Dead and injured cattle ignored while multiple government agencies pass the buck2025-03-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:20ZLexisNexisDead and injured cattle ignored while multiple government agencies pass the buck

Dead and injured cattle from an overturned livestock truck were ignored by authorities for weeks while multiple state government agencies, councils, and insurance companies bickered over who was responsible.

A truck crash that left 60 head ofcattle dead, dying and injured by the side of a road in north-west Victoria has prompted calls for a better animal welfare response from state authorities.

Warning: This story contains images of dead animals that some readers may find distressing.

When the livestock carrier rolled near the small town of Patchewollock on February 11, a total of five state government agencies, two local councils, and two insurance companies were called in to respond.

But none claimed responsibility for removing the carcasses, euthanasing the injured cattle, rounding up the runaways, or providing food and water. 

Instead, farmers were left to deal with the mess and the bureaucratic buck-passing that followed.

Patchewollock farmer Ash Jackson found himself as the point of contact on the ground, fielding hundreds of calls from various agencies for days.

"Over 70 phone calls I had for the day on Wednesday and then same again on Thursday, backwards and forwards," Mr Jackson said.

Those agencies included Victoria Police, Agriculture Victoria, Forest Fire Management Victoria, Parks Victoria, VicRoads, Mildura Rural City Council, Yarriambiack Shire Council, a livestock agency, a transport company,and insurance companies Elders and Sedgwick.

The ABC understands that, three weeks later, seven head of cattle remain on the loose.

A brief timeline

When the cattle truck rolled on that Tuesday evening in February, 13 animals died and the remainder fled the scene.

The 60-year-old driver of the truck was not injured.

Mr Jackson was called in and spent three hours with local CFA crews dragging dead and injured cattle from the truck.

"The tow truck company were going to take the dead cattle on the ground away, however, [Agriculture Victoria] made contact and said they'd take care of everything," Mr Jackson said.

That never happened.

When Mr Jackson returned on Wednesday morning, he said the carcasses were untouched, and 16 head of cattle were walking on the road "looking around for what to do and where to go".

He again made contact with Agriculture Victoria, as he understood them to be the agency in charge, and was told "there was no plan in place".

Over the next few days, as temperatures soared into the 40s, Mr Jackson was promised "all sorts of things" from Agriculture Victoria — planes, gyrocopters, holding yards, troughs, water, feed, signage, and a "clean-up crew for the carcasses".

"At one point, there were people organised to come on horseback, and sure enough that never happened," Mr Jackson said.

In text messages seen by the ABC, Agriculture Victoria conceded the operation had been "a balls-up". 

Mr Jackson said the only action taken by any organisation was to remove VicRoads signage that warned locals about cattle on the road.

"Now locals think [the] job is done and everyone else passing through has no clue of any hazards," he wrote in a text message to Agriculture Victoria.

Patchewollock farmer Simon Grigg — one of many who volunteered to help — called the response an "absolute disgrace" and said no-one had any idea who was in control or responsible for the animals.

"If a farmer did this, we'd be prosecuted," Mr Grigg said.

"A couple of these animals collapsed and died when we tried to give them water and [Agriculture Victoria] claim to be worried about cruelty to animals."

Agriculture Victoria did not comment on whether its handling of the incident constituted an animal welfare issue.

RSPCA Victoria told the ABC this was a matter for Agriculture Victoria.

"Any matters regarding more than 10 head of commercial livestock are under their jurisdiction — this is part of the [Memorandum of Understanding] RSPCA Victoria have with them," a spokesperson said.

Who's responsible?

In short, no-one knows.

Victoria Police, whose officers were first on scene and initially in charge deferred the case to Forest Fire Management Victoria and Parks Victoria.

Parks Victoria does not manage state forests, the Department of Energy, Environment and Climate Action [DEECA] does.

DEECA, who gave the ABC a joint statement on behalf of Forest Fire Management Victoria and Agriculture Victoria, did not comment on which agency was responsible but said it was "working with local authorities and the livestock carrier to capture the remaining cattle".

In an earlier statement, a spokesperson for Agriculture Victoria — which, according to local farmers, assumed the role of chief liaison — said it assisted with animal welfare concerns at traffic incidents "when requested".

However, the ABC understands that the bulk of the clean-up and care of cattle post-accident was done by farmers.

While wandering cattle are typically the responsibility of local shires, both Yarriambiack and Mildura councils said this case was not their responsibility because the stock were wandering in a state park.

Yarriambiack Shire Council officers directed the ABC to Victoria Police, the Department of Transport and Planning, and Mildura City Council, while Mildura council officers directed the ABC to Victoria Police and Agriculture Victoria.

The Department of Transport and Planning said its jurisdiction was exclusively roads and traffic management.

Meanwhile, the livestock agent said this was an issue for Agriculture Victoria and insurance companies.

The two relevant insurance companies declined to comment.

The ABC understands one of the insurance companies assigned a maritime expert to assess the cattle truck rollover, which allegedly caused a hold-up in the clean-up.

Who should be responsible?

According to Emergency Management Victoria's State Emergency Management Plan, Victoria Police is responsible for road crashes and Agriculture Victoria manages anything involving animal welfare.

But the chief operating officer of Livestock and Rural Transporters Association of Victoria, Alina Hawkins, said the "first point of contact" for any emergency involving heavy vehicles carrying livestock should be the national hotline LivestockAssist.

"Unfortunately, in this case, the protocol was not followed due to extraordinary circumstances," Ms Hawkins said.

She said, typically, LivestockAssist would liaise with Agriculture Victoria on incidents like this, and the two agencies would coordinate the clean-up and after-care in conjunction with the livestock carrier, cattle owners, and tow truck operator.

urn:contentItem:6FRJ-V983-RRMY-73FD-00000-00'Taking its toll': residents left in the lurch after bushfires2025-05-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:20ZLexisNexisNEWS7'Taking its toll': residents left in the lurch after bushfiresJessica Greenan

Residents with damaged property wondering who'll reimburse them.

Concern has been raised about the inability of some south-west residents to be reimbursed for damage to property caused by authorities reaching fire zones.

The issue was raised by Southern Grampians Shire councillor Adam Campbell and director of infrastructure and sustainability Marg Scanlon at the council's April 2025 meeting.

Councillors were discussing a fire recovery plan in the aftermath of fires at the Grampians National Park which burned from December 2024 to February 2025 when Ms Scanlon described issues that'd risen from it.

She highlighted the situation of an individual who served as "just one example".

"The example was that, at the time of the fire, that individual was approached and requested to gain access through their private property for the various services to go and manage the fire," she told the public meeting.

"That resulted in significant fencing and damage to that property which in typical circumstances the first point of call was that insurance would cover that.

"This individual, as others are doing, is working through that process only to learn there is no insurance coverage.

"The state government has also categorically said there is no opportunity to claim any of those costs back through the state government - that really is taking its toll on individuals.

"Certainly there's still a lot of momentum and energy to keep pushing in terms of what opportunities there are, but as you'd appreciate, after months of green drought and fires, that certainly leads to a lot of pressures on individuals and families and the community, so it's a significant issue."

A state government spokesperson said it wasn't true it didn't offer any opportunities to claim costs back for damaged property if someone's land was accessed to reach a fire.

The spokesperson said a Repair of Rural Fencing Policy Doc was available on Forest Fire Management Victoria's website in the 'public land recovery' section.

They also said Ms Scanlon's example did not contain enough detail to respond to.

An Insurance Council of Australia spokesperson said claims were dealt with on a case-by-case basis.

"When an insurance customer makes a claim, it is assessed against their cover and policy, including all terms, inclusions and exclusions outlined in the Product Disclosure Statement (PDS)," they said.

"Claims relating to property damage are assessed on a case-by-case basis in line with the PDS, which vary between insurers.

"The ICA recommends policyholders regularly review their policy to understand what they're covered for, and where appropriate, enlist the support of a broker to ensure you have the right cover for your needs."

The April meeting also provided insight into the council and community's response to the fires.

Council documents show it opened emergency relief centres in Dunkeld and Hamilton. Monivae College also provided use of their facility at no cost.

The sites were used to provide temporary accommodation for more than 16 displaced individuals.

Displaced pets and animals were given accommodation at the Hamilton Pound and Hamilton Regional Livestock Exchange.

Bottled water was supplied to Glenthompson, where the water supply was disrupted. An alternative option was provided by Wannon Water.

The Glenthompson Outdoor Swimming Pool was used as a water source and storage for fire management purposes.

At Hamilton Aerodrome, the council supplied water, and, through support from Wannon Water, increased water pressure which reduced refilling time for airtankers and water bombers.

A neighbouring business, Sustainable Plastic Solutions, altered its operations to reduce its water demand during the fire period.

Council documents note the tourism sector was severely impacted. It stated infrastructure within the park, including the Grampians Peaks Trail, would be closed for a long period.

The southern end (Dunkeld) would be cut off from the northern end until such time works were scoped.

Southern Grampians Shire Council has revealed some residents are struggling to receive compensation for damaged property in the aftermath of the Grampians National Park bushfires. File picture.

urn:contentItem:6FX8-6G13-RWG3-H1RJ-00000-00Mayor praises 'reprieve for farmers' in ESVF backflip after councillors slam tax2025-06-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:20ZLexisNexisMayor praises 'reprieve for farmers' in ESVF backflip after councillors slam taxBryan Hoadley

Councillors were 'united' in slamming the emergency services tax.

Ballarat's mayor says the city is pleased to hear the state government will cap its Emergency Services and Volunteer Fund (ESVF) levy for all primary production properties across Victoria, after councillors labelled the tax increase "cruel", "toxic" and "out of touch".

At a council meeting on May 28, 2025, the council unanimously passed a motion condemning the new tax as a "significant financial burden" on Victorian property owners.

The motion also called on the city to advocate for the responsibility for the collection of the ESVF to be transferred to the Victorian Treasury and for the council to write to relevant state ministers and local MPs denouncing the new tax.

Mayor Tracey Hargreaves said she was concerned by the "significant financial burden" it would place on residents, but the council was unable to refuse to collect the tax.

While deputy mayor Ben Taylor said the municipality's emergency services levy total sat at $10 million in 2020, and it would rise to $22 million under the new ESVF.

It comes after The Courier revealed that Ballarat ratepayers would see an average increase in emergency services-related payments of 45.9 per cent.

This includes a 34 per cent increase in levy charges for residential property owners on their 2025-26 rates notices, while primary production properties are facing a 148 per cent increase.

The ESVF, which was passed by parliament in the early hours of May 16, is replacing the cheaper Fire Services Property Levy and has been met with widespread fury from rural residents and councils, who feel disproportionately affected by the new tax.

Under the ESVF, additional funds will go to services including VICSES, Triple Zero Victoria and Forest Fire Management Victoria, which were not supported by the previous levy.

Just days later, on Friday, May 30, the government announced that the levy would be capped at the 2024/25 rate for all primary production properties across the state for the coming financial year.

"We understand that the rate for primary production properties will remain at 28.7, the same as it was in 2024/25 for the duration of the 2025/26 financial year," Cr Hargreaves said, following the announcement.

"This is hard-fought recognition of the unique difficulties farmers are currently facing in devastating drought conditions.

"Despite this welcome reprieve for farmers, council remains committed to the motion that was passed on Wednesday night in which all nine councillors voted to formally oppose the Emergency Services and Volunteers Fund and the mandated requirement to collect it on behalf of the state government."

ESVF a 'crushing burden' for rate payers

On Wednesday night, the first to speak in favour of the motion was councillor Ted Lapkin, who called the ESVF a "crushing burden" for Victorian farmers.

In an impassioned speech, Cr Lapkin quoted protester placards, The Financial Review and an 1819 US Supreme Court decision, and compared the City of Ballarat to ancient Roman tax collectors.

He also called on the community to pressure their local MPs over the "outrageous tax".

"To this Labor government, country Victoria is expendable and exploitable, it sees rural regions as a source of low-hanging revenue fruit that can be taxed to the hilt," he said.

"The Victorian government's emergency services tax will destroy livelihoods and perhaps even lives ... we must express our dissent in the strongest possible terms.

"Only if ordinary Victorians exert sustained political pressure do we stand any chance at all of repealing and reversing this toxic tax."

Cr Lapkin's motion was then seconded by councillor Jay Morrison, who was also critical of the burden the ESVF would put on the city's ratepayers.

"The timing of this levy could not be worse; we are in the midst of a cost-of-living crisis," he said.

"We are not just making a statement, we are taking action, we are standing up for our community and are calling for a better, fairer approach."

When voicing his support for the motion, Cr Taylor said it would send a "clear message" that the tax was unacceptable, particularly for businesses and farmers who would experience the steepest rises.

Councillor Des Hudson recommended that future rates notices should highlight how much money would go to the ESVF, and also include contact information for state MPs so ratepayers could voice their concerns regarding the tax.

"This is unfair, it's a burden, it's at a time when we can least afford it, and we deserve a better outcome," he said.

'Mental health problems': Concerns for farmers highlighted

Councillor Samantha McIntosh and councillor Damon Saunders both cited concerns for farmers' mental health while outlining their support for the motion.

"This cruel impost is going to create mental health problems," Cr Saunders said.

"This cruel and sneaky tax is abhorrent."

In also opposing the ESVF, councillor Jim Rinaldi said members of the state government "wouldn't have any idea what it's like to struggle for a dollar" and that they were "out of touch" with the ordinary person.

Finally, councillor Tess Morgan said she was "proud to hear a united voice among councillors" and urged the council to keep its share of the rates low when it came to its forthcoming budget.

"I'm proud this appears to be a [council] group aware of the cost of living," she said.

Neighbouring council voices strong opposition to ESVF

On Tuesday, neighbouring council Hepburn Shire passed a similar motion, which voiced strong opposition to the ESVF.

In a press release, the Hepburn Shire stated it would "join the many other councils opposing the levy".

While the ESVF is proving unpopular with regional councils, earlier in May, Ballarat's MPs defended their decision to back the new legislation .

When explaining her stance on the ESVF, member for Wendouree Juliana Addison cited the need for more funding for emergency services to combat the increase in climate change-related disasters.

"We need to create a funding model that is sustainable in a world where disasters are going to become a more common occurrence," she said.

"That was at the forefront of my supporting this bill, making sure that our volunteers are supported."

Member for Eureka, Michaela Settle, and Member for Ripon, Matha Haylett, also voted in favour of the ESVF, but both cited rebates for drought-affected farmers and CFA and SES volunteers as an important aspect of the legislation.

"I have always fiercely fought for my community in Parliament, and I will continue to do so," Ms Haylett said.

"I know this is a very difficult time for many members of our community, particularly farmers, with drought conditions and bad harvests."

City of Ballarat councillors have criticised the Victorian Government's ESVF legislation at a May 28, 2025, council meeting. File picture

urn:contentItem:6FND-V253-RRV4-M06W-00000-00These firefighters saved us, but they might be missing next time2025-04-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:20ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 16These firefighters saved us, but they might be missing next timeLachlan Abbott

Australia's bushfire-fighting capacity is at risk from airborne assets being used overseas, writes Lachlan Abbott.

On December 12, Victoria's 54-strong aerial firefighting fleet was unveiled at Avalon Airport. Within days, they were needed.

On December 17, lightning sparked a fire in the rugged Grampians, which was tinder-dry after 18 months of little rain.

The fleet - included several water-bombing helicopters, a clutch of smaller cropduster-style planes, and two large air tankers, owned by Canadian company Conair and operated by Australian partner Field Air - had work.

Over the next four weeks, an airborne assault dropped 5723 payloads of water and retardant as ground crews often struggled to reach flames in inaccessible terrain. Those payloads helped save the popular tourist town of Halls Gap from an inferno with a 422-kilometre perimeter.

To show exactly how they did it, The Age has combined flight and fire data with accounts from those on the ground.

Some helicopters hoovered water up from dams. Other aircraft guided commercial-size firebombing jets. A few planes scouted for flare-ups. And one helicopter used an infra-red camera to scan through thick smoke and help authorities issue alerts.

Forest Fire Management Victoria's deputy incident controller Glenn Rudolph said better weather and a significant ground effort to build control lines ultimately contained the blaze, but an intense aerial attack was crucial in buying time.

It's why Craig Lapsley, Victoria's first emergency management commissioner, fears any loss of the state's biggest firebombing aircraft - currently procured through contracts with international aviation companies - could seriously hinder firefighting efforts when they are needed most.

Lapsley points to the Los Angeles winter fires as evidence of climate change driving year-round threats, potentially tying up firebombers overseas that Australia would otherwise use.

"Victoria, I think, may struggle in years to come with the availability of large aircraft," Lapsley says. "They're living on an old model that may have serviced Victoria very well ... but I think they're missing an opportunity."

The aftermath

The first Grampians bushfire scorched more than 76,000 hectares of national park and farmland. Four homes in Moyston and Mafeking were lost along with 40 outbuildings. Thousands of animals died.

And yet, it could have been worse.

Amid the LA fires in January, The Age reported Australia risked losing large international waterbombing aircraft as climate change lengthened fire seasons, keeping planes busy in the northern hemisphere. Underscoring the risk were deadly and record-breaking fires in South Korea last month.

NSW felt the affects of prolonged fire danger in the mid-2010s when early season starts - such as in 2018 - meant the Rural Fire Service (RFS) was unable to immediately get all the planes needed from overseas. That prompted the RFS to pursue its own standing fleet to guarantee some sovereign capability, starting with the acquisition of a 737 air tanker in 2019.

"Ever since then, the availability [of large firebombers] has become even more pressured," RFS commissioner Rob Rogers said. "There's a real shortage of these things around the world, so there's a lot of competition."

NSW's top firefighter said the LA fires meant American demand would remain strong. South American countries such as Argentina and Chile, whose southern hemisphere summer fire seasons nearly mirror Australia's, were increasingly seeking planes too, he added. "You've also got some of the European countries, particularly Greece, that used to rely heavily on the Russian machines. And obviously, since the Ukraine situation, that's become problematic," Rogers said.

The Black Summer fires spurred a further expansion of the NSW fleet, including the purchase of a large Chinook helicopter in 2023. Although the cost may be hefty, Rogers said "the cost increases were just nowhere near as volatile when you own the asset".

Some of the state's fire-bombers are still contracted from aviation companies via the National Aerial Firefighting Centre. But the NSW fleet employs and trains locals under a $400 million, 10-year operations deal with Canada's Coulson Aviation.

Victoria does not have a standalone fleet like this, which ex-Emergency Management Victoria chief Craig Lapsley thinks is a problem.

"I'm not one to say Victoria has got it dramatically wrong," he said. "I just think Victoria's got a risk of not having what they want, when they need it, under the current arrangements."

Lapsley argued an investment would be worthwhile even if there were no fires to fight over winter, as crews could tackle other natural disasters and train. He pointed out that a NSW large air tanker recouped some money as it was briefly sent to tackle fires overseas, albeit a small amount.

Alternatively, the contract-model could be enhanced, Lapsley suggested, by increasing operation days each year so planes remained in Victoria consistently. "We shouldn't have to rely on bringing people from overseas if you build the industry in Australia," he said.

Field Air general manager Stephen Holding said Victoria already had some sovereign capacity as one of its Q400ATs, which is ultimately owned by Canadian company Conair, is based at Avalon year-round, operating in Queensland before Victoria and then staying in Australia over winter for maintenance.

"It's just been offered a contract structure that provides enough days commercially for an operator to leave it here. It doesn't have to go and do another season somewhere else in the world. And that's another way you can achieve sovereignty without the taxpayer having to fund it," he said.

Josephine Stirling, director of the National Aerial Firefighting Centre, which co-ordinates aircraft procurement for states and territories, said seven aircraft moved between North America and Australia this bushfire season as part of their contracts. She indicated that increasing competition for them was an issue.

"With changing fire seasons globally and demand for the larger resources growing, this arrangement will be challenged in future years," she said.

Asked if direct investment in aircraft like NSW was being considered, Forest Fire Management Victoria's chief fire officer, Chris Hardman, backed the current contract-model.

"This approach, delivered through Victoria's Emergency Management agencies, ensures we have an effective, flexible and innovative aviation firefighting capability to help fight fires and keep Victoria's community, assets and environment safe," he said.

"Aircraft are just one tool to keep the community safe. In any given season, our aircraft fleet supports thousands of firefighters, hundreds of firefighting trucks, heavy machinery and plant equipment on the ground."

Acting emergency management commissioner Tim Wiebusch said Victoria was "well resourced" to fight fires with aircraft.

"The majority of aircraft in the Victorian fleet are locally based and the state has contractual and contingency arrangements in place to ensure appropriate aircraft are available across the higher risk weather season," he said. "Victoria also has access to more than 100 call-when-needed aircraft that are available year-round to respond to emergencies."

Ex-NSW fire chief Greg Mullins has long called for Australia to develop more sovereign aerial firefighting capacity. But he stresses that firebombing from the sky couldn't stop bushfires altogether, and boots on the ground would always be needed.

"It's overrated in the public's eye," he said. "It's of great assistance in certain circumstances, but it's not a silver bullet, and never will be."

Mullins pointed out that severe weather might stop planes from being able to fly safely, as happened in the Grampians on Boxing Day, or break up retardant drops. In the first Grampians fire this summer, only 50 drops - albeit those with the biggest payloads - were from large air tankers.

"It takes some intensity out of the fire, and slows it down and gives the ground forces a chance. [But] worldwide, firefighters know aerial attack does not extinguish fires," he said. "People on the ground do."

urn:contentItem:6DXY-XPD3-S039-M0NN-00000-00The threat is reduced: Grampians' Boroka Lookout bushfire downgraded2025-01-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:20ZLexisNexisThe threat is reduced: Grampians' Boroka Lookout bushfire downgradedStaff Reporters

FFM Victoria boss believes fire most likely caused by campers.

Update 7.30pm: While the bushfire is not yet under control, Forest Fire Management Victoria has downgraded the threat to neighbouring communities.

In an alert just after 7.30pm, FFMVic said the spread of the bushfire has slowed, but the situation could change at any time.

"It is not safe to return to the Boroka Track area," the message said.

"There is currently no threat to Halls Gap township."

Residents were advised aircraft could be seen or heard working throughout the night.

Update 4.30pm: Fire crews continue to water bomb an out-of-control bushfire just one kilometre north of Halls Gap.

Since 10pm on January 19, Forest Fire Management Victoria crews have worked around the clock to contain a bushfire on Boroka Track, west of Halls Gap.

Crews from Great Western, Halls Gap, Pomonal, Stawell, AFIB, Moyston, Dadswells Bridge and Glenorchy & Riachella continue to battle the blaze from the ground.

As of 12pm, the bushfire has burnt about seven hectares.

More to come.

Update 12pm: FFM Vic chief fire officer Chris Hardman said authorities believe the bushfire outside Halls Gap resulted from 'irresponsible' campers.

"I'm really disappointed to see we have a fire just two kilometres north of Halls Gap," he said.

"This fire was most likely caused by campers or people who that lit a fire over the railing on the edge of the Boroka Lookout.

This community has been through enough."

Mr Hardman said the "reckless" campers had put the community at risk for no reason.

He urged anyone with information regarding the fire to contact the police immediately.

"We will do our best to contain this fire and protect the community," he said.

Earlier 8.30am:Forest Fire Management Victoria issued a 'Watch and Act: Leave Now' warning for people on the Grampians Peak Trail following the growth of a bushfire west of Halls Gap.

A blaze west of Halls Gap on the Boroka Track is moving southerly towards the Wonderland area.

"Don't wait; leaving now is the safest option - conditions may change and get worse very quickly.," the warning said.

"Emergency services may not be able to help you if you decide to stay."

People walking the Grampians Peak Trail should leave the area immediately; however, the township of Halls Gap can remain.

FFM Vic said Bellfield, Fyans Creek and Grampians Junction residents should monitor conditions.

Crews from Great Western, Halls Gap, Pomonal, Stawell, Moyston, Dadswells Bridge, Glenorchy & Riachella are battling the blaze as it moves towards Mount Victory Road.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:

www.emergency.vic.gov.au

VicEmergency Hotline - free call 1800 226 226

VicEmergency app

Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires)

Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility:

The following services can help you or someone you know access information during an emergency.

To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (free call) and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment, contact National Relay Service at 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

urn:contentItem:6FG3-VST3-RXTY-C326-00000-00You might see smoke at your place as planned burns get underway across state2025-04-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:20ZLexisNexisYou might see smoke at your place as planned burns get underway across state

Farmers are also completing private burns.

Smoke may be visible across parts of Victoria in the coming weeks due to planned and private burns.

Conditions are ideal for burning, but weather patterns may cause smoke to linger over some parts of the state overnight and into the early morning hours.

Forest Fire Management Victoria chief fire officer Chris Hardman said it was crucial fire agencies took advantage of favourable conditions when they presented.

"Planned burning on public land is one of the tools FFMVic uses to keep Victoria safer from bushfires," Mr Hardman said.

"Our climate is changing and that means finding the right days for safe and effective planned burning is becoming more challenging."

Mr Hardman said autumn typically provided crews more opportunities to conduct planned burns.

"With the current favourable weather and forest conditions, we are delivering as much planned burning as we can," he said.

"Reducing dry vegetation such as grass, leaves, bark, shrubs and small fallen branches means fires are less intense and slower to spread, making it more likely that firefighters can keep bushfires small and contained before they pose a risk to communities.

"We work closely with Country Fire Authority (CFA), Environment Protection Authority and Bureau of Meteorology to keep the smoke impact from planned burns as low as possible.

"We make every effort to make sure favourable weather conditions reduce smoke drift into communities."

CFA chief officer Jason Heffernan urged Victorians to ensure they had the correct permit requirements before conducting private burn-offs.

"We are now starting to issue schedule 13 permits to farmers to burn crop stubble to kill off weeds and reduce pests," Mr Heffernan said.

"However, we remind Victorians that no burning off is to occur unless people have received permission.

"It is vital that landowners check local conditions are safe and appropriate before burning off - both on the day and the days following."

Farmers are also asked to let their neighbours know about planned burns.

"Any burning off activity should have enough water and resources on hand to monitor and extinguish and Triple Zero Victoria must be notified as awareness for emergency services and community members," Mr Heffernan said.

The Planned Burns Victoria website has details of all planned burns currently on the three-year Joint Fuel Management Program.

Victorians have been warned they may see smoke in the coming weeks due to planned burns. File picture

urn:contentItem:6FPP-YW63-RRW7-D3FV-00000-00'Taking its toll': residents left in the lurch after bushfires2025-05-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:20ZLexisNexis'Taking its toll': residents left in the lurch after bushfiresJessica Greenan

Residents with damaged property wondering who'll reimburse them.

Concern has been raised about the inability of some south-west residents to be reimbursed for damage to property caused by authorities reaching fire zones.

The issue was raised by Southern Grampians Shire councillor Adam Campbell and director of infrastructure and sustainability Marg Scanlon at the council's April 2025 meeting.

Councillors were discussing a fire recovery plan in the aftermath of a series of fires at the Grampians National Park - which burned from December 2024 to February 2025 - when Ms Scanlon described issues that'd risen from it.

She highlighted the situation of an individual who served as "just one example".

"The example was that, at the time of the fire, that individual was approached and requested to gain access through their private property for the various services to go and manage the fire," she told the public meeting.

"That resulted in significant fencing and damage to that property which in typical circumstances the first point of call was that insurance would cover that.

"This individual, as others are doing, is working through that process only to learn there is no insurance coverage.

"The state government has also categorically said there is no opportunity to claim any of those costs back through the state government - that really is taking its toll on individuals.

"Certainly there's still a lot of momentum and energy to keep pushing in terms of what opportunities there are, but as you'd appreciate, after months of green drought and fires, that certainly leads to a lot of pressures on individuals and families and the community, so it's a significant issue."

'Case-by-case basis'

A state government spokesperson said it wasn't true it didn't offer any opportunities to claim costs back for damaged property if someone's land was accessed or damaged to reach a fire.

The spokesperson said a Repair of Rural Fencing Policy Doc was available on Forest Fire Management Victoria's website in the 'public land recovery' section.

The spokesperson also said Ms Scanlon's example did not contain enough detail to respond to.

An Insurance Council of Australia spokesperson said claims were dealt with on a case-by-case basis.

"When an insurance customer makes a claim, it is assessed against their cover and policy, including all terms, inclusions and exclusions outlined in the Product Disclosure Statement (PDS)," they said.

"Claims relating to property damage are assessed on a case-by-case basis in line with the PDS, which vary between insurers.

"The ICA recommends policyholders regularly review their policy to understand what they're covered for, and where appropriate, enlist the support of a broker to ensure you have the right cover for your needs."

Emergency response

The April meeting also provided insight into the council and community's response to the fires.

Council documents show it opened emergency relief centres in Dunkeld and Hamilton. Monivae College also provided use of their facility, at no cost to the council.

The sites were used to provide temporary accommodation for more than 16 displaced individuals.

Displaced pets and animals were given accommodation at the Hamilton Pound and Hamilton Regional Livestock Exchange.

Bottled water was supplied to the town of Glenthompson, where the water supply was disrupted. An alternative option was provided by Wannon Water.

The Glenthompson Outdoor Swimming Pool was used as a water source and storage for fire management purposes.

At Hamilton Aerodrome, the council supplied water, and, through support from Wannon Water, increased water pressure which reduced water refilling time for airtankers and water bombers.

A neighbouring business, Sustainable Plastic Solutions, altered its operations to reduce its water demand during the fire period.

Council documents note the tourism sector was severely impacted during the fire period. It stated tourism infrastructure within the park, including the Grampians Peaks Trail, would be closed for a long period.

The southern end (Dunkeld) would be cut off from the northern end until such time works were scoped.

Southern Grampians Shire Council has revealed some residents are struggling to receive compensation for damaged property in the aftermath of the Grampians National Park bushfires. File picture.
